title: Overview
desc:
This interactive visualization explores changes in Tibetan Identity using contemporary Tibetan artist Gonkar Gyatso’s artwork as a guide to the geopolitical, religious, and cultural aspects of Tibet, from traditional times to the modern Tibetan diaspora.

Each of the four panels reflects a different period for Tibet. Ciicking one of the Identity segments provides an indepth view of the period using the artwork as a guide, and clicking on individual dots will dig deeper into topics within that view.

Traditional Tibet

Provide a historical context of the traditional elements in Tibetan culture including art, religion, and society that continue to serve as the backbone of Tibetan culture today by examining the culture and practices of traditional Tibet prior to 1950 and effects of modernization.

China and Tibet

Visually represent the causes and ramifications of China and Tibet  from 1959 to present day. It explores the ways in which Tibetans reacted to China's actions, the international responses to this humanitarian issue, as well as how daily life and Tibetan identity have ultimately been changed.

Indian Diaspora

With the first mass exodus beginning in 1959, this portion seeks to understand how people of the Tibetan Diaspora fleeing to India have retained certain aspects of their culture while also understanding how leaving their homeland has changed religious practices, political structures, and daily cultural life.

World Diaspora

Examining the hybridization of Tibetan identity and culture following the post-1980 global diaspora.

About this project

This project was created in an undergraduate seminar at the University of Virginia Introduction to the Digital Liberal Arts (Media Studies 3703), a project-based learning class that uses interactive technology to explore topics in the humanities. All opinions expressed are solely the responsibility of the students themselves. Click story(here,process) to see details on the process.

title: Traditional Tibet
desc:
This visualization explores change in Tibet by using contemporary Tibetan artist Gonkar Gyatso’s My Identity series composed of four photographic self-portraits that depict his conception of different aspects of Tibetan identity across time and space.

The first self-portrait, which features Gyatso as a traditional Tibetan painter, is based on a photograph of Tsering Dondrup, the Thirteenth Dalai Lama's senior court painter, taken in 1937 by the American photographer Charles Suydam Cutting. Cutting was one of the first Westerners to enter the forbidden city of Lhasa, the capital of Tibet (You can enlarge the photograph on the left by clicking on it). In this and the other self-portraits in the series, Gyatso assumes the pose of Tsering Dondrup.

This initial composition in the series shows Gyatso painting a thangka, a traditional Tibetan painting on cloth, that has Shakyamuni Buddha as its central figure. The Buddha is depicted displaying a bhumisparsha, “Earth Witness,” mudra. Gyatso wears the clothing and jewelry of a traditional Tibetan aristocrat and is surrounded by art utensils from pre-1950 Tibet. The whole setting is carefully constructed to take us back to the spaces of traditional Tibetan homes and monasteries. The colorful walls exhibit thangkas that have their silk covers veiling the paintings; a wood-carved table holds fine hair brushes, bowls with mineral pigments, and a silver-lidded teacup; a matching traditional cabinet has a flower vase on top.

Two elements remain the same in all of Gyatso’s four compositions: a little black wooden box and the artist’s pose. The initial template for Gyatso’s identity, Tsering Dondrup’s photograph, lingers across all the self-portraits. These recurring images form a connection between the different Tibetan ways of being, invoking the intricacies and complexities of the artist’s own search for a Tibetan identity.

title: Avalokiteśvara
desc:
Avalokiteśvara, the bodhisattva of compassion, is one of the most well-known bodhisattvas in the Buddhist tradition. The worship of the bodhisattvas, also known as beings of enlightenment, is a distinctive feature of Mahāyana Buddhism. A bodhisattva is a spiritually realized being who is on the path to becoming a Buddha, one who has discovered true wisdom and attained nirvana. Avalokiteśvara is worshipped throughout Buddhist Asia and is Tibet’s patron deity.

Avalokiteśvara plays a central role in many traditional accounts, being depicted as the progenitor of the Tibetan people and also as instrumental in the spread of the dharma in Tibet. When the Tibetan plateau was first formed, its only inhabitants were a monkey and an ogress. The monkey was an incarnation of Avalokiteśvara who was peaceful and contemplative, and focused on mediation. The ogress was lustful and emotionally untamed. After some hesitation on the part of the monkey, the two finally got together and produced six children.

Tibetans today see themselves as descendants of the monkey and the ogress. While society was still primitive, Buddhism was far too complicated for the people to understand, so Avalokiteśvara helped the people to eventually reach a level of maturity where they could embrace dharma over time.

Buddhism is said to have appeared in Tibet during the reign of the 23rd monarch of the Yarlung dynasty, Totori Nyentsen (c. fourth century). Buddhist texts and relics are said to have fallen from the sky in Sanskrit, consecrated to Avalokiteśvara. The arrival of these holy texts was planned by Avalokiteśvara and marked the beginning of Buddhism in Tibet. However, during the reign of Songsten Gampo (seventh century) who was the first of three religious kings and an incarnation of Avalokiteśvara, Buddhism was firmly established (Powers).

In Tibet, the Dalai Lama is considered to be a manifestation of this bodhisattva. A bodhisattva is an individual who in on the path to becoming a Buddha. A Buddha is one who has discovered true wisdom and attained nirvana. In Tibet, anyone who aspires to reach awakening is considered to be a bodhisattva. Om Maņi Padme Hūm is the most important and well-known mantra associated with Avalokiteśvara, who is Tibet’s patron deity.

For religious practitioners, the mantra is a form of the name of Avalokiteśvara and the innermost heart of Avalokiteśvara. By chanting the mantra, one hopes to see Avalokiteśvara and appropriate the bodhisattva’s power, developing in this way great compassion and ultimately achieving liberation. Click link(here,http://religion.oxfordre.com/view/10.1093/acrefore/9780199340378.001.0001/acrefore-9780199340378-e-167) for more information.

In Tibet, anyone who aspires to reach awakening is considered to be a bodhisattva. Tibetan Buddhism teaches its followers that we are all potential Buddhas, encouraging them to develop the characteristics of those who are enlightened by practicing meditation. There is great emphasis on the lama, the Tibetan equivalent of guru. Lamas are spiritual teachers whose long life of study and practice allows them to be placed in the role of bestowers of initiations and esoteric teachings. Tibetan Buddhists believe that a deceased lama can intentionally reincarnate in the body of a child in order to continue his or her spiritual activities. Click link(here,https://www.sakya.org/introtibetanbuddhism.html) for more information.

title: The Third Dalai Lama
desc:
The Third Dalai Lama, Sonam Gyatso (1543-1588), was a great spiritual master and scholar. Sonam Gyatso gained the reputation as “Virupa of Tibet” because of his efforts to prevent floods in the Jokhang, the most sacred temple in Lhasa (the reference here is to the famous exploits of great mahasiddha Virupa in controlling water). Sonam Gyatso conducted flood-averting rituals and aided with the construction of dikes. In 1563, he taught monks in the Sera, Drepung and Gawadong monasteries in Lhasa to help to repair dikes, and to protect Lhasa on the last day of the Great Prayer Festival. He clearly played a key role in acting as the protector of Lhasa.

A powerful dynasty emerged in Tibet in the middle of the sixteenth century. The rulers of that dynasty, the Tsang kings, became important patrons of the Kagyu School, a rival of the Gelug School, the school of the Dalai Lamas. The Gelug School tried to compensate for the disadvantage through seeking the patronage of Mongol leaders.

The prestige of Sonam Gyatso led Altan Khan, an important Mongol leader, to invite him to Mongolia, inaugurating an alliance that had profound implications for the authority of the Dalai Lama incarnation line. When Altan Khan met Gyatso in 1578, he was very impressed with him, and gave him the title “Dalai” meaning “ocean” in order to symbolize that he was an ocean of learning and wisdom. This is how the title Dalai Lama began and was retroactively conferred on Sonam Gyatso’s predecessors.

title: The Fifth Dalai Lama
desc:
Ngawang Lobsang Gyatso came to power in 1642, and became the most dynamic and influential of the early Dalai Lamas, earning his title as “The Great Fifth” (Powers). His rise would bring Buddhism to the center of Tibetan life. The Fifth Dalai Lama paved the way for the reestablishment of a centralized government in

Tibet through his alliance with Gushri Khan, an important Mongol leader. The new government established by the Fifth Dalai Lama was named Ganden Podrang after the residence of the Dalai Lamas in Drepung Monastery. The Ganden Podrang government ruled the vast stretches of territory under its jurisdiction through a small bureaucracy in a kind of federation system. In that context, the many religious festivals were important in keeping the cohesion of the kingdom.

The Great Fifth himself and his regent Sangye Gyatso played a huge role in the creation of rituals and state cosmology through their many writings and government actions. The Fifth Dalai Lama build his own public image through these writings, tying together prominent Tibetan mythic and historic figures to the lineage of the Dalai Lamas. Those connections were further deepened in rituals, festivals and the creation of artistic objects and architecture.

The Fifth Dalai Lama had a tumultuous childhood. Shortly after his birth, his father became involved in a plot against the Tsang king, resulting in his arrest in death and 1626. In 1618, the year he was arrested, Central Tibet and Tsang fought deathly battles, possibly as a result of disagreements between the Gelug and Kagyu schools. In the early 1630s, representatives from the Sera, Drepung and Ganden schools contacted Mongol leaders around the borders of Tibet, which would eventually lead to the conquest of political power by the Gelug School.

Sonam Chöpel was one of these representatives, and was primarily responsible for discovering the Fifth Dalai Lama. In the Fifth’s writings, Chöpel is seen as a great mediator between the lama and Gushri Khan who was the young leader of the Qosot Mongols. After Gushri Khan took control of the Tsang region between 1637 and 1641, he and Sonam Chöpel organized a welcoming party to greet the Fifth at Dechen, between Lhasa and Shigatse. Khan offered the Fifth many gifts, and a few weeks later a formal ceremony was held in the Samdrubtse Castle, the old headquarters of the Tsang dynasty.

The Fifth Dalai Lama and the Gelug School would be able to establish a long-term governmental structure and politically unify an important part of the Tibetan cultural territory. Chöpel, Khan and the Dalai Lama decided to build the Potala Palace, which would become one of the main symbols of the new Tibetan government. The Fifth Dalai Lama had intense mystical visions, largely as a result of his studying at the Nyingma School and personal past connections to Avalokiteśvara, Songsten Gampo, Padmasambhava and Atisha Dipamkara. Overall, he hoped to bring a new centralized government through the assimilation of symbolic modalities prevalent in the Tibetan imaginary of the time.

title: The Fourteenth Dalai Lama
desc:
Tenzin Gyatso, The Fourteenth Dalai Lama is the current Dalai Lama. He was born on July 6, 1935 in northeastern Tibet, and recognized as the reincarnation of the Thirteenth Dalai Lama when he was two years old. At age six, the Fourteenth Dalai Lama began his monastic education with the greatest effort towards Buddhist philosophy. When he turned twenty-three years old, he took his final philosophy exams in the Jokhang Temple and was awarded the Geshe Lharampa degree, which is equal to the highest doctorate in Buddhist philosophy. In 1950, the year the Chinese occupation started in Tibet, he was formally enthroned as political and spiritual leader of the country according to Tibetan protocol. A few years later, in 1956, the Chinese would try to incorporate his political capital by appointing him Chairman of the recently-established Preparatory Committee for the Autonomous Region of Tibet (PCART). The political situation in Tibet forced him to escape into exile in 1959. Since 1960, he has lived in Dharamsala in northern India. title: The 14 Dalai Lamas
desc:
There have been 14 Dalai Lamas. since the 15th century and they are the emanations of Avalokiteśvara, the bodhisattva of compassion. There is more information on Dalai Lamas that have images on their circles, shown here by clicking on them.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4549/37767520385_fc6cc5ffc3_o_d.jpg)The First Dalai Lama was Gendun Drubpa (1391-1474). He founded the Tashilhunpo monastery in Shigatse, Tsang. Tashilhunpo became a pivotal point in central Tibet between two other Gelug monasteries, providing homes for thousands of monks. Drubpa played a huge role in the Gelug School’s rise to power. The personal and institutional renown that he developed through his scholarly and spiritual accomplishments awarded him great recognition as a politically important lama.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4556/38622872122_13128a4394_o_d.png)The Second Dalai Lama, Gendun Gyatso (1475-1542) was recognized as a reincarnation of Gendun Drubpa in 1475. He built many monasteries, both small and large including Chokhorgyal, which is 90 miles southeast of Lhasa. Gyatso served as abbot of Tashilhunpo and Drepung monasteries. With this role, he made Lhasa the center of operations for the Dalai Lamas to come. In addition, he built a residence in Drepung, Ganden Podrang that would later come to inspire the Fifth Dalai Lama in establishing the name of the government. Gyatso was similar to the First Dalai Lama in that he also had many spiritual and scholarly accomplishments, allowing them both to become major players in the patron-priest relationship style of doing politics in.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4580/38598998456_6fccdff6f1_z_d.jpg)The Third Dalai Lama, Sonam Gyatso (1543-1588), was a great spiritual master and scholar. Sonam Gyatso gained the reputation as “Virupa of Tibet” because of his efforts to prevent floods in the Jokhang, the most sacred temple in Lhasa (the reference here is to the famous exploits of great mahasiddha Virupa in controlling water). Sonam Gyatso conducted flood-averting rituals and aided with the construction of dikes. In 1563, he taught monks in the Sera, Drepung and Gawadong monasteries in Lhasa to help to repair dikes, and to protect Lhasa on the last day of the Great Prayer Festival. He clearly played a key role in acting as the protector of Lhasa.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4584/38599001846_fd9e35be18_z_d.jpg)Fourth Dalai Lama, Yonten Gyatso, was the great-grandson of Altan Khan was recognized as the Fourth Dalai Lama in 1588. He lived a short life – he died in 1616 at the age of 28 “under mysterious circumstances.” However, he was still accomplished in his short life. He helped to politically strengthen the Gelug School through his ties to his great-grandfather. Bringing Mongol blood into the powerful Dalai Lama line propelled the Tsang kings to later put a ban on the recognition of the next incarnation in the Dalai Lama’s line.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4578/38655048561_a75e53da80_b_d.jpg)The Fifth Dalai Lama, Ngawang Lobsang Gyatso came to power in 1642, and became the most dynamic and influential of the early Dalai Lamas, earning his title as “The Great Fifth” (Powers). His rise would bring Buddhism to the center of Tibetan life. The Fifth Dalai Lama paved the way for the reestablishment of a centralized government in

Tibet through his alliance with Gushri Khan, an important Mongol leader. The new government established by the Fifth Dalai Lama was named Ganden Podrang after the residence of the Dalai Lamas in Drepung Monastery.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4530/37789913695_8f599081fb_o_d.png)The Sixth Dalai Lama: Tsangyang Gyatso, was born in 1683 in the family of the terton Padma Lingpa and Tsewang Lhamo. Sangye Gyatso, the last regent of the Fifth Dalai Lama, concealed the death of the Tibetan leader for fifteen years. Hence, even though he discovered the Sixth Dalai Lama when he was five years old, Sangye Gyatso raised and educated him in secret. It was only in 1697 that Tsangyang Gyatso was formally recognized as the Dalai Lama. At that point, the death of the Fifth Dalai Lama could no longer be hidden. Tsangyang Gyatso was the first Dalai Lama to live as a layman. He is known to be a poet, fond of alcohol and brothels in Shol, a village to the south of the Potala Palace.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4544/24782799398_1d3587e061_b_d.jpg)The Seventh Dalai Lama, Kelzang Gyatso was born in 1708. At eight years old he was escorted to Kumbum by a Chinese-Tibetan-Mongol cavalry. In 1720, he was enthroned in the Potala Palace, and was fully ordinated in 1726. When the Seventh Dalai Lama reached the age of 43, he created a council of ministers in order to administer the Tibetan government. This also allowed him to become to spiritual and political leader of Tibet. He wrote many books, with focus on the tantra. He died in 1757, but Tibetan citizens were quite fond of him for his simple and unblemished life.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4516/38622876702_a23e25ca30_z_d.jpg)Jampel Gyatso was the Eighth Dalai Lama (1758-1804). During his time as Dalai Lama, an army from Nepal invaded Tibet. The Eighth Dalai Lama had to rely on the help of the Chinese army to defeat the invaders from Nepal. In 1781, the Eighth Dalai Lama took full responsibility of the government after resisting for quite sometime, as he was focused on his own education and spiritual practice.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4549/38655055761_1ca24bedc2_b_d.jpg)The Ninth Dalai Lama, Lungtok Gyatso (1805-1815) is known for dying very young. When he was born in a village near the Denchokor Monastery, many thought he was an orphan, but other sources are able to identify his parents. He was brought to Lhasa and enthroned in 1808. In 1811, the Ninth Dalai Lama held the first meeting between a Dalai Lama and a British citizen. He was meeting with Thomas Manning, who just opened a medical clinic in Lhasa. In 1815, at the age of 9, the Dalai Lama caught a cold, and it unfortunately took his life.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4515/38598999896_729e0cedfb_o_d.png)Tsultrim Gyatso was the Tenth Dalai Lama (1816-1837) and was born into an important Tibetan noble family. He was chosen out of 6 candidates to become the Tenth Dalai Lama, but before he was enthroned, the regent who enthrones the Dalai Lama died. Once he became Dalai Lama, he was given several different tutors, and started studying sutra and tantra beginning at age 10. In 1834, an epidemic broke out in Lhasa, and the Dalai Lama had to be confined to the Potala, and he died at age 22.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4562/38622869512_8b015865eb_o_d.png)Khedrup Gyatso (1838-1856) was recognized as the Eleventh Dalai Lama in 1840, and was enthroned 2 years later. He was born in the same village as the Seventh Dalai Lama. During his reign, Chinese influence over Tibet weakened as a result of the wars of Ladakh, Opium Wars and Taiping Rebellion. This would allow the Twelfth Dalai Lama to protect Tibetan culture from the west more thoroughly. Unfortunately, only in 1856, one year after he assumed full control of the government, he died.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4559/24782803858_3ae0cd5e09_o_d.png)Trinle Gyatso (1857-1875) was one of three candidates to become the Twelfth Dalai Lama, and upon coming to Lhasa, he was able to identify personal objects of the Eleventh Dalai Lama, indicating that he was the reincarnation. When he turned five years old, he was enthroned, and became primary monk at age nine. He started to attend the annual Lhasa Monlam in 1868, and was the first Dalai Lama to do so. At age 13, he took full control of the government. At age 19, he entered nirvana at the Potala palace, and his corpse is preserved there.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4577/38622877682_a6ef95bee0_o_d.png)Thirteenth Dalai Lama: Tubten Gyatso (1876-1933) Tubten Gyatso was discovered when he was two years old, and arrived in Lhasa at that time. One year later, the Dalai Lama was formally enthroned. When the Dalai Lama turned six years old, he began his religious training. Unfortunately, the Thirteenth Dalai Lama had to deal with the British presence in India. In 1885, the British attempted to send mission to Lhasa, but Tibet refused their military’s attempt at entering. In 1888, the two armies had their first armed conflict after fighting over land. This led to the “Anglo-Chinese Convention Relating to Sikkim and Tibet.” The Dalai Lama was hesitant about assuming political power until he reached age 20. In fact, he continued to show disinclination towards taking on political duties until 1895, when the National Assembly of the Tibetan Government called on him to assume power. The peace broke two years into his reign, as the Chinese launched a military attack to attempt to gain control of Nyarong, an area governed by Lhasa. The Thirteenth Dalai Lama decided to dispatch a secret mission, leading to the eventual withdrawal of the Chinese soldiers. At age 24, the Dalai Lama started having recurring dreams, seeing his life in constant danger. Later he would find out that his regent, the Ninth Demo, was trying to murder him using a pair of “enchanted boots.” During his lifetime, the Thirteenth Dalai Lama did pilgrimage to holy places in Tibet, and later in other countries. While traveling, the Thirteenth Dalai Lama was exposed to transformations occurring around the world, which showed him that perhaps Tibet was lagging behind. As a result, he attempted to bring political and social reform to Tibet.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4581/38623754922_f46bcc7801_z_d.jpg)Tenzin Gyatso, The Fourteenth Dalai Lama is the current Dalai Lama. He was born on July 6, 1935 in northeastern Tibet, and recognized as the reincarnation of the Thirteenth Dalai Lama when he was two years old. At age six, the Fourteenth Dalai Lama began his monastic education with the greatest effort towards Buddhist philosophy. When he turned twenty-three years old, he took his final philosophy exams in the Jokhang Temple and was awarded the Geshe Lharampa degree, which is equal to the highest doctorate in Buddhist philosophy. In 1950, the year the Chinese occupation started in Tibet, he was formally enthroned as political and spiritual leader of the country according to Tibetan protocol. A few years later, in 1956, the Chinese would try to incorporate his political capital by appointing him Chairman of the recently-established Preparatory Committee for the Autonomous Region of Tibet (PCART). The political situation in Tibet forced him to escape into exile in 1959. Since 1960, he has lived in Dharamsala in northern India.

title: The Next Dalai Lama
desc:
In 1969, the Fourteenth Dalai Lama made clear that recognizing a reincarnation following his life will be a decision for the Tibetans, the Mongolians, and the Himalayans. In September 2011, the Fourteenth Dalai Lama declared that when he is ninety years old, he would assess whether the institution of the Dalai Lama should continue after him.

He noted that if a Fifteenth Dalai Lama is recognized, the officers of the Dalai Lama’s Ganden Podrang Trust would hold the primary responsibility. He also said that he would leave clear instructions and that without legitimate methods, no recognition should be given to a chosen Dalai Lama for political reasons, including any reasons from China. title: Art and Architecture
desc:
Art

Until the mid-twentieth century, most of Tibetan visual art was created for religious purposes. Much of traditional Tibetan art depicts the Buddha himself or Buddhist values. Traditional  art is typically in the form of murals, tangka paintings, and mandalas.

Click further to learn more about these forms of Tibetan art and their significance in history and society.

Click booklet(here,artbook) for a booklet about art.

Murals: video story of a 1000 year old mural discovered in temple renovation shows how strong mural history is: iframe(https://www.youtube.com/embed/Fhq3cFOc9rI)

Tangkas: video showing the importance of rules in tangka painting iframe(https://www.youtube.com/embed/dseQhufTvyU)

Mandalas: time lapse video of the creation of traditional mandalas iframe(https://www.youtube.com/embed/r2PQg6mws4k)

Architecture

In order to visualize the unique building style of Tibet and how it ties into the practice of Buddhism, this section on traditional Tibetan architecture serves to provide a base for the understanding of important religious structures and living spaces.

Tibetan architecture scholar Andre Alexander wrote on Tibetan architecture’s distinct "Tibetan" visual identity. Some of these formal elements he found through research include buildings built into the rocky landscape, thick black window and door frames, and flat roofs.

pic(https://snowbrains.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/132316782_61n.jpg)The Potala was built into its rocky terrain, stretching thirteen stories into the sky, and placated just so that most of the city of Lhasa is viewable from it. Similarly to the Jokhang and most traditional Tibetan architecture, nails are not used in the construction and its walls are comprised of local stone and mud materials. Its walls slope inwards, as a way of providing support in the rocky environment. Myth suggests that the Potala took about fifty years to be built, and suggests that Songtsen Gampo constructed the Potala as a defensive structure.

pic(http://img1.vtibet.com/en/calture/architecture/201407/W020140731644295781705.jpg)The Potala is comprised of two parts: the White Palace and the Red Palace. The White Palace contained the Dalai Lama’s dwellings, whereas the Red Palace contained a maze of monastic spaces.
Importantly, contained in the Potala’s Red Palace are eight golden stupas, holding the embalmed corpses of the Fifth Dalai Lama, as well as those of the Seventh to Thirteenth Dalai Lamas.

pic(https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3a/Bundesarchiv_Bild_135-BB-094-10%2C_Tibetexpedition%2C_Blick_auf_die_Potalastadt.jpg)

The Zhol Village, “the divinity dwells in the palace, and underneath, at the distance of a furlong or two, humanity is huddled abjectly in squalid smut-begrimed houses. The proportion is that which exists between God and man” (Candler). The Zhol Village contained residential spaces for the local government, administrative offices for the military and government as well as printing presses and a jail. Today, the Zhol Village has largely been razed by the Chinese government, and Beijing Avenue and Liberation Square displacing the families and destroying this historic village.

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4521/38031232204_d36008624a_o_d.png)After the the Jokhang Temple was constructed, Songsten Gampo built Lhasa up by collecting very valuable and sacred statues of bodhisattvas of Avalokiteshvara. Most of the Jokhang ’s use is for chapels, dormitories for monks, as well as space for the Panchen and Dalai Lamas.


pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4560/38031232264_d54fb76d28_o_d.png)The most important chapel in the Jokhang contains a very sacred statue of Jowo Shakyamuni, the Buddha. This chapel allows for the innermost circumambulation to take place inside the Jokhang. The wooden door of the Jowo chapel is carved with detailed images of bodhisattvas, evoking an Indian style that Songtsen Gampo was heavily inspired by in the creation of the Jokhang . Upon entering, the marks of several centuries of Saga Dawa celebrations, in remembrance of the Buddha’s nirvana, are evident. As described by Sarat Chandra Das in his journey to Lhasa in the late 1800s, the Saga Dawa celebrations involve many devouts approaching this important image of Jowo, “[carrying] in their hands bundles of incense-sticks, bowls of butter, and khatag of all sizes and qualities” (Das)

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4528/38031232084_2956edcf0c_o_d.png)Of architectural interest, the Jokhang is secured by a myriad of ornate, detailed pillars, depicting narrative elements of Tibetan Buddhism. The columns are intricately detailed, bracketed with inscriptions of animal heads, bodhisattva moldings, foliage, and aristocratic images of jewels. As Das goes on to describe, some of these inscriptions on the pillars can contain “charms against devils, for curing diseases, and for keeping off and thwarting the evil designs of the enemies of Buddhism and of the government of the Church.”

pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4547/38031232324_a51cc5a11c_o_d.png)Above the Jowo Chapel entrances, carved juniper wood lion heads mount the pillars, illustrating some of the detail that went into the Jokhang.

title: Traditional Art
desc:
pic(http://www.asianart.com/articles/rockart/large/11.jpg)Tibetan murals began and evolved from rock painting in caves. These paintings typically depicted animals like sheep, ox, horse and hunting scenes. (picture shows yak hunting)page()pic(http://static.newworldencyclopedia.org/e/e4/Wall_mural._Ralung_Gompa%2C_Tibet._1993.jpg)When Buddhism came to Tibet between the 5th and 7th centuries, rock paintings began to represent Buddhist culture and values. Eventually, rock and cave paintings evolved into murals. Many murals, especially early traditional ones, depict prominent Buddhists figures surrounded by detailed settings. Others depict significant figures, events, myths, and Tibetan social life. Murals are prevalent on walls, ceilings and hallways of temples and palaces. Only expert artists know how to paint the murals traditionally because they are elaborate and follow strict guidelines and principles.page()pic(http://img3.vtibet.com/en/calture/artpainting/201407/W020140731641982979913.jpg)This mural is inside the Potala Palace and it shows Tibetans celebrating the completion of the palace in the 17th century by dancing and performing.page()pic(https://cdntct.com/tct/pic/city/tibet/lhasa/shopping/thangka-03.jpg)Tangka Paintings A tangka is a scroll painting that is typically used for Buddhist teaching purposes. They are often hung like banners in monasteries or over family altars. Tangkas can be rolled up when they are not being used for religious purposes. Tangkas can either be painted or embroidered on cotton cloth, paper, or silk. The composition of tangkas is very geometric and the proportions are essential to the art. It takes expert painters and the mastery of rules relating to the number of hands, color of deity’s face, posture, symbols, and more to create traditionally correct tangkas. Tangka painters are trained for years to become masters and the master lineage often stays in the family.page()A popular tangka subject is the Tibetan Wheel of Life which represents the six realms of existence according to the Abhidharma teachings. (next image)page()pic(http://www.onmarkproductions.com/assets/images/wheel-of-life-Tanka-TN-6.jpg)page()pic(https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/93/Amitayus_Mandala.jpeg) Mandalas are diagrams of symbolic, geometric patterns that chart the succession of the initiations of Buddhas in history. Mandalas represent a physical existence and space for enlightened versions of Buddhas. Mandalas are used by Buddhists as maps and aids to meditation.page()pic(http://static.newworldencyclopedia.org/thumb/9/96/Painted_19th_century_Tibetan_mandala_of_the_Naropa_tradition%2C_Vajrayogini_stands_in_the_center_of_two_crossed_red_triangles%2C_Rubin_Museum_of_Art.jpg/600px-Painted_19th_century_Tibetan_mandala_of_the_Naropa_tradition%2C_Vajrayogini_stands_in_the_center_of_two_crossed_red_triangles%2C_Rubin_Museum_of_Art.jpg)Mandala literally means “that which encircles a center” and they usually contain and outer circular mandala pattern with an inner square. Often, there are intricate images of Buddhist relics with multiple symbolic meanings surrounding the Buddha depicted. This adds to the meditational direction and meaning of the image.page()pic(http://www.mountainsoftravelphotos.com/Tibet%20-%20Buddhism/Top%2010%20Symbols/Top%2010%20Symbols/slides/08-2%203-D%20Kalachakra%20Mandala.jpg)Mandalas are usually painted or woven on scrolls and hung inside temples for guidance to enlightenment. There are also sand mandalas (video) and 3D mandalas like Kalachakra at the Potala Palace (on left)page()pic(http://www.mandala-painting.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/sand-mandala-dismantling.jpg)Sand mandalas are a Tibetan tradition. They are carefully created over several weeks by multiple expert monks. Ultimately, they are ritualistically destroyed to symbolize the Buddhist belief of the ephemeral aspects of material life.page()pic(https://i.pinimg.com/originals/6f/08/bb/6f08bb285a9cc56b514ac6fd84027796.jpg)

The five main colors in mandalas represent the five main Buddhas, values of enlightenment, and natural elements.

White: Buddha. Learning and Knowledge. Air

Green: Karma. Balance and Harmony. Water

Red: Padma. Life Force and Preservation. Fire

Yellow: Ratna. Rootedness and Renunciation. Earth

Blue: Vajra. Purity and Healing. Space

title: Tibetan Environment
desc:
The Environment

For thousands of years, the Tibetan people who occupied the land tended it with Buddhist religious ideas to live in harmony with nature. Many traditional Tibetans were nomads who moved at the pace of the yak to best utilize the unique geography and land of Tibet. Those who lived in cities also followed a main ideal of Buddhism to nurture and respect their environment. Until the 1950s, Tibet was essentially untouched by the modern world. Today, many traditional practices and Buddhist ways of life relating to nature are still present in Tibet. Continue on to learn about the geography, animals, plants, and climate of Tibet that have and do affect the Tibetan way of life.

Tibetan Geography and Climate:

Now called The Tibet Autonomous Region, Tibet is located in the Southwest portion of China and makes up about ⅛ of China’s territory. Tibet’s geography is unique due to its diverse landscape including the Himalayan Mountains and deep rivers and valleys. Tibet’s varying terrain causes its climate and weather to also vary. High altitudes create some harsh, dry, and cold weather, while lower altitudes allow for a more mild climate. Click booklet(here,geo/climate) for a better look into Tibetan geography and climate

iframe(https://www.youtube.com/embed/F3HZdiUUyqo)

Native Animals:

Tibet supports various ecosystems and wildlife due to the large range of elevations and environments. Most of the land is considered montane grasslands with both tundra like environments and forests. Click booklet(here,animals) for a booklet on animals.

Native Plants:

The main crops and a staples of a traditional Tibetan diet are barley, wheat, and flax. These crops are common due to their ability to withstand frost, and early evidence shows they have been a staple since 1400 BC. Tibet also has a history of herbal plant medicines. Click booklet(here,plants) to learn more about Tibet’s native plants.

title: Tibetan Geography and Climate
desc: pic(https://lonelyplanetwp.imgix.net/2010/06/IMG_0149.JPG?fit=min&q=40&sharp=10&vib=20&w=1470)The main geographical regions can generally be divided into the east, north, and south.The Eastern part of Tibet is made up of mainly lush forests and river filled gorges.page()pic(https://www.tibettravel.org/assets/images/tibet-travel-advice/changthang-grassland.jpg)The Northern part of Tibet is mainly made up of open grasslands. The Southern and central region of Tibet is described as the agricultural region. Lhasa and the major cities and towns are in this region. The next picture shows the Potala Palace in Lhasa in the 1940s.page()pic(http://photogrvphy.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/08/tibet-life-in-forbidden-lhasa-1940s-and-50s-01.jpg)page()The next three images show the range of altitude and elevations in Tibet. First is Holy Mount Kailash at an altitude of 4,500 meters. Next, is a modern day picture of the Potala Palace at an altitude of 3,650 meters. Finally, is a picture from the Southeastern city, Nyingchi. At an altitude of 3100 meters, it is the city with the lowest altitude in Tibet.page()pic(https://www.tibettravel.org/assets/images/tibet-tour-guide/geography-and-environment/mount-kailash2.jpg)page()pic(https://www.tibettravel.org/assets/images/tibet-tour-guide/geography-and-environment/potala-palace.jpg)page()pic(https://cdn1.i-scmp.com/sites/default/files/styles/980x551/public/images/methode/2017/04/22/e2befc7c-23d8-11e7-a553-18fc4dcb5811_image_hires_114807.JPG?itok=_ud47ji8)The majority of Tibetan land is made up of the Tibetan plateau. The Tibetan plateau is dubbed “The Third Pole” and is considered a “Roof of the World.” It is the highest and largest plateau in the world with points of elevation from 4,600 feet to 16,000 feet. Tibet stores the third largest amount of water-ice in the world and is the source of many rivers in Asia. It is bordered by the Inner Himalayas on the South and the Kunlun mountains on the North.page()pic(https://i2.wp.com/www.circleofblue.org/wp-content/uploads/2008/05/122_china_tibet_Texture-cop.jpg)Southern and Central Tibet have generally temperate, livable climates while Northern Tibet has a colder, harsher climate. Generally, Tibetan winter allover is cold, dry, and long and Tibetan summer is mild and rainy at night from May to September.page()pic(http://www.rucsacs.com/images/gallery/147.jpg)page()pic(http://www.kreisels.com/tibet2004/photos/tsari/tsari-6953.jpg)page()pic(http://www.rucsacs.com/images/gallery/147.jpg)In the mountains, weather changes abruptly and knowledge of the land is important. Temperatures can get as low as -30 degrees fahrenheit in the winter.page()pic(https://www.tibettravel.org/assets/images/namtso-lake/namtso-700-1.jpg)In some areas in the summer, temperatures can reach 100 degrees Fahrenheit during the day. At night temperatures can drop to the fifties which makes the summer a popular time to travel to Tibet. Namtso Lake is a very popular destination for photography in the summer from May to September. (pictured to the left)page()Changes in seasons are less apparent in Southern and central Tibet than in Northern Tibet, and the winter is more mild. The next two pictures show the Potala Palace in the winter versus the palace in the summer.page()pic(http://www.tibetpandatours.com/public/richfiles/photos/Lhasa%20Photos/potala%20palace/budalagong-2.jpg )page()pic(http://anutreks.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/12/potala-palace-in-lhasa-14-days.jpg)page()pic(https://freetibet.org/files/styles/full_natural_desktop/public/23-9-15_Great_Tibet_Robbery.jpg?itok=Q3C3rZBS&timestamp=1444055398) Since the Chinese came into Tibet, many natural resources have been exploited and harmed.

title: Tibet's Native Animals
desc: pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4571/38095262384_56917c5cd6_z_d.jpg)Before the 1950s, travelers compared Tibet to East Africa (pictured on left) due to the abundance of herds of large wild mammals. However, deforestation and overhunting after the Chinese invasion has harmed the diversity and quantity of Tibetan wildlife. There are over 140 species of mammals, 40 species of reptiles, 50 species of amphibians, and 400 species of birds native to Tibet.page()pic(http://en.people.cn/NMediaFile/2017/1009/FOREIGN201710091533000438018136137.jpg)page()In the forest regions these mammals include tigers, leopards, bears, boars, goats, langur monkeys, and buffalo.In the dry grassland regions these mammals include musk deer, antelope, brown bears, sheep, yaks, and donkeys. The reptiles, amphibians, and aquatic life in these regions include snakes, scorpions, frogs, fish, otters, and turtles.page()pic(http://tibetnature.net/en/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/Bengal-Tiger.jpg)page()pic(https://www.tibettravel.org/blog/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/28.jpg)page()pic(https://i.pinimg.com/originals/32/18/69/321869ae721d5b9a9b7065ada16c2d5d.jpg)page()pic(https://weblog.savetibet.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/tibet-sheep.jpg)page()pic(http://ichef.bbci.co.uk/naturelibrary/images/ic/credit/640x395/t/th/thermophis_baileyi/thermophis_baileyi_1.jpg)page()pic(https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/bf0d1fb5f0480c50a1272a48e44481016d259439/688_0_5587_3355/master/5587.jpg?w=700&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=23f0ec74b1aee7d7eb7c421c65040676)

title: Tibet's Native Plants
desc: pic(http://chinatibet.people.com.cn/mediafile/201208/07/P201208071021243240511151.jpg)Most agriculture is grown in Southern Tibet because of its more stable climate.The main crops and a staples of a traditional Tibetan diet are barley, wheat, and flax. Other crops that can withstand the Tibetan climate include potatoes, buckwheat, peas, mustards, dry land rice, corn, red peppers, pumpkins, radishes, and cabbage.page()pic(https://www.tibettravel.org/assets/images/tibet-travel-advice/ongkor-festival-tibet.jpg)page()pic(https://scontent-lga3-1.cdninstagram.com/t51.2885-15/e35/23734581_1489173788050653_3797857112462196736_n.jpg)page()pic(https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/e9/Tibet_labourDSCN1911.JPG)page()pic(http://www.tibetan-buddhist-art.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/tibetan-medicine-healing-plants-herbs.jpg)Traditional Tibetan medicinal practices have a history of over 3800 years. Ancient Tibetans found many native plants, herbs, and minerals useful for healing purposes. The ancient medical theory, “where there is poison, there is medicine; medicine and poison are of coexistence, which can transform into each other” is considered the first Tibetan medicinal idea. Buddhist ideals to align with nature in order to reach a higher self are present in Tibetan medicine.page()pic(http://holistic-health.org/boulder/wp-content/uploads/2010/01/saka-dawa-06-chagpori-clinic-opening-KTM-July-Thrushik-rinpoceh-087.jpg)Ancient people looked to nature for help and guidance to survive in the harsh environment in Tibet. Common plant and herb examples and their uses in Tibetan remedies include Rhododendron, Barberry, Snow Lotus, and Sea Buckthorn.page()pic(https://www.insidehimalayas.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Bandera-Nepal.jpg)Rhododendron is found in the Himalayas. Its extracts and oils from the leaves, flowers, bark, and twigs are traditionally used for the treatment of inflammation, common colds, skin conditions, and intestinal problems.page()pic(https://sites.lsa.umich.edu/mueggler/wp-content/uploads/sites/347/2017/04/berberis-forrestii.jpg)Barberry is a deciduous shrub grown on the plains. Remedies come from both the bark and extract of the flower and berry. Traditionally barberry was used to help eliminate poisons, drain lymphs, and calm inflammatory eye problems. It is a detoxifier.page()pic(https://dl0.creation.com/articles/p116/c11693/lotus.jpg)Snow Lotus is a plant that grows at very high elevations and thrives in harsh environments. Extracts from its leaves and flowers are used medicinally as an anti-inflammatory. It is commonly used for arthritis.page()pic(http://image.tibet.cn/images/2016/10/17/201610171476672587142_175.jpg)Unfortunately, the snow lotus is now highly endangered due to its high demand and limited natural environment.page()pic(http://www.seabuckthorninsider.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/04/sea-buckthorn.jpg)Sea Buckthorn is a deciduous shrub found in high elevations in Tibet. The fruit itself is very high in vitamin C, which helps immunity and allergies. Its oil is rich in fatty acids which helps with inflammation and palmitoleic acid which helps heal burns and wounds.

title: Tibetan Festivals
desc:
pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4585/23885940507_cd6592e871_o_d.jpg)The Tibetan calendar contains twelve lunar months, with an intercalary month every year in order to maintain cohesiveness with the solar year. As a result, the first month can be between February and March if aligned with the western calendar. The Tibetan calendar is based on a sixty-year cycle called rabchung, in which twelve animals are combined with five “elements.” In this system, fire, water, earth, iron, or wood are associated to the mouse, ox, tiger, hare, dragon, snake, horse, sheep, monkey, bird, dog and pig years, making a total of sixty years. The 1st, 8th and 15th days of each month are all important days for each is dedicated to religious observance. In the pre-Chinese invasion Tibet, the lunar calendar was punctuated by a succession of public ceremonies and festivals that were almost always religious in nature.page()pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4583/23885941677_1c4013c5d2_b_d.jpg)The New Year begins with two ceremonies in which the Dalai Lama receive special guests in the Potala: Lama Losar, the “Priest’s New Year,” and the Gyalpo Gosar, the “King’s New Year” In the morning, the Dalai Lama wakes up to a ceremonial drum-roll, followed by private prayer. There is a short reception for high officials. Next the Dalai Lama goes into a formal procession on the 2nd floor of the Potala for “the accumulation of blessings for a peaceful existence.” This is followed by a formal ceremony where the Dalai Lama is served tea from a monk in a golden teapot, and several dances. Servants then bring in food, and distribute it to guests at the Dalai Lama’s permission. Following the closing precession, all the guests go home, and hold their own family celebrations with New Year presents. Every household decorates its altar, and trades scarves, wheat and barley.page()pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4557/38750418531_956ecf1c53_b_d.jpg)Preparations for the Great Prayer Festival, the main public festival in Tibet, begin on the 3rd day of the first month. Monks from the Drepung, Sera, Ganden monasteries head to Lhasa in the morning to take part in the Great Prayer Festival. The monks struggle to find a spot in the Jokhang Temple to sit, and stay at night. The main prayer hall in the Jokhang cannot hold more than 5,000 people at a time. There is an abbreviated prayer services, but on the 5th day, regular daylong prayer sessions begin. Sometimes, during these sessions there are also debates between candidates vying for high religious degrees. During morning sessions, tea, rice and meat are served, whereas in the afternoon only tea is served. The government funds all the activities.page()pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4516/38750418391_57bc28e2cd_b_d.jpg)On the 10th day, a ceremony called ‘The Time for the Gathering of the Skygoers” begins, where high officials, monks, and laymen head to the Meru Temple following the first prayer session. After several weeks of ceremonial rituals of for the Great Prayer, the 24th day marks the casting out of the Votive Offering for the Great Prayer. Mönlam Torgya is the most spectacular New Year celebration, and the longest ceremony as well. Cavalierly are joined by foot soldiers called Zimchongpa. The patio in front of the Jokhang is the center of activity where the offering takes place.  On the 25th day, there is a ceremony called the Jampa Dendren. As the moon is in its last quarter, high officials and onlookers gather in front of the Jokhang, and a cart is dragged in a clockwise manner circuit of the Barkor, and monks carry banners, incense and ritual vessels. Each day in the first month is quite eventful and makes up the events of the Great Prayer.page()pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4561/23885941377_1fb5bc1e3f_b_d.jpg)page()pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4557/38750418211_2d3460bb21_b_d.jpg)page()pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4516/38750417851_0d4afcbf22_b_d.jpg)The 19th day of the second month marks the celebration of the death of the Fifth Dalai Lama known as The Great Assembly of Worship. Sangye Gyatso, the last disciple of that great Tibetan king, started this festival in 1682. This is one of the many yearly celebrations created by Sangye Gyatso to commemorate the newly established government of the Dalai Lamas, the Ganden Podrang. In the case, of the Great Assemply of Worship, the prayer services lasted twelve days, and were done so on a much smaller scale than the Great Prayer festivals. Since the Fifth Dalai Lama’s death occurred in 1682, but was not publicized until 1697, there is some discrepancy about when the Great Assembly of Worship officially began.page()
pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4556/23885940897_54bfbaca02_b_d.jpg)Over the years, other festivals commemorating the Dalai Lamas were created. The 5th day of the fifth month marks the Birthday Festival, which celebrates the birthday of the Thirteenth and Fourteenth Dalai Lamas. The Potala Palace and the Norbulingka palace, as well as various temples are decorated with colored flags, burning green incense from their rooftops. The Dalai Lama spends time with his family privately, and then goes to a small lake in the Norbulingka palace. After going to various pavilions for ritual activities, the Dalai Lama and his family go to Trunglha Gönkhang, which is a small temple located two miles from Lhasa. Scarves and incense are offered before they go to a summerhouse for a period of several days to entertain various guests.page()pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4564/23885940747_12b25bcf9e_b_d.jpg)On the 25th day of the sixth month, there is a celebration of the birth of the Eighth Dalai Lama. Kyitseluding is the site of the festival, where dancers perform Ache Lhamo, a kind of Tibetan opera, to honor the god Lichinhara, the Trunglha, birth-god, of the Eight Dalai Lama.

title: Chinese Tibet
desc:
Gonkar Gyatso's second painting in his series depicts a Tibetan identity that is the result of Chinese invasion and control over the region since 1950. These vast changes on life in Tibet are indicated through various objects in the painting. The influence of China on Tibetan culture is made very clear when looking at the stark changes from the first painting. 

The Picture of Mao

Presumably a painting of Mao. The connection here is with the political climate of the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s the specific details leading to China’s arrival in Tibet and the Cultural Revolution, and, in general, the various geopolitical aspects of the Communist influence in Lhasa.

The Wall of Pamphlets

Seems to be made out of various leaflets from the time period, instead of the bright, religious colors from the previous picture. These were frequently handed out during the Cultural Revolution. Could be used to discuss the various interruptions to daily religious life caused by the political turmoil happening at the time, and forced compartmentalization of Buddhism under Chinese occupation.

The Clothing

Chinese Soldier’s uniform. There could be a link here to the discussion on the various acts committed by the Chinese military in Lhasa (burning of temples, execution/humiliation of monks, etc.), as well as the general effects of Tibet’s gradual transformation into a pseudo-police state

The Furniture/Chest

Same chest as in the previous painting, only repainted red (Communist color). Lead into discussion of the destruction and repurposing of Tibetan buildings and living spaces after the arrival of the Chinese.

Bust of Mao

Instead of the flower from the previous picture, a statue of, again, presumably Mao, or some other communist leader. There could be a link here to the discussion of the Chinese’s disrespect of the Tibetan natural landscape, and their general interruption of the traditional Tibetan relationship with the land.

title: Occupation
desc:
Invasion and Preliminary Occupation (1950-1958)

The People's Liberation Army invaded Tibet on October 7th in 1950 bringing 40,000 troops into the country. China invaded primarily to gain land and the vast amount of natural resources present in the area. Shortly after the invasion or “liberation,” in China's eyes, the 14th Dalai Lama signed the Seventeen Point Agreement with the Chinese government. This agreement placed the Dalai Lama as the ruler over Tibet and established Chinese sovereignty over the region. 

In 1959, the 14th Dalai Lama fled to India on March 17th disguised as a soldier in order to escape Communist controlled Tibet. His escape was a large turning point for the power the Chinese government could exert over the region. With the Dalai Lama out of the government, China could implement the Great Leap Forward program in Tibet. 

The Great Leap Forward (1958-1962)

Started in 1958 by Mao, the Great Leap Forward had as its main goal to collectivize the citizens of China into specialized communes that would produce one specific product for the rest of the country. It would be considered one of the biggest policy disasters in history as a result of those living in the collectives inflating what they produced to tax collectors and the compulsory state purchases of grain at a fixed price. The result of this was a death toll which some estimate is as high as 55 million people. This massive famine is illustrated zoomer(here, https://i1.wp.com/www.scottmanning.com/wp-content/uploads/2009/03/chinadeathratecalories1955-1964.png?w=481). The high death toll is also evident in the effect of the world's birth rate. In short, the dimension of the policy failure of The Great Leap Forward was so great, it could be measured in terms of the effect it had on the world's population zoomer(here, https://ourworldindata.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/Updated-World-Population-Growth-Rate-Annual-1950-2100.png).

The Cultural Revolution (1966-1976)

Initiated in 1966 by Mao, the Cultural Revolution sought to promote communist ideals among those living in China as better than liberal/capitalistic ideas. Red Guard was formed by the youth of the country and many, many senior members in the government were the victims of Mao’s purges. As many as 1.5 million died, but many more millions were subject to struggle sessions where they were tortured. The Little Red Book played a huge role in influencing millions during the Cultural Revolution, by spreading the teachings of Mao to those living under the Communist regime. Mao sought to eliminate what he called the "Four Olds" meaning Old Customs, Old Culture, Old Habits, and Old Ideas. 

Both of these major political moves by Mao’s regime greatly affected Tibetans who just after seeing their country be invaded by China saw their entire system change. Monks and Nuns were forced out of monasteries to work in collectives. All were forced into a regime that was trying to change its own country's years old traditions and saw their way of life changed forever. 

In 1962, the Tenth Panchen Lama wrote the 70,000 Character petition to Zhou Enlai which discussed the oppression of the Tibetan people. It is considered to still be the most detailed discussion on China's policies in Tibet. It includes his firsthand experiences of seeing monasteries destroyed in the name of "religious freedom" under Communist control. This text was not released until 1996, a very telling fact about the control China exerts over the region. 

Destruction of Monasteries 

Before the Chinese exerted control over Tibet, the region was home to more than 6,000 Buddhist monasteries. After the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution, only 8 monasteries were unscathed. Here we know the locations of just 580 monasteries, one can only imagine what over 6,000 would look like. Since the 1980s, Tibetans have started to rebuild, only some of the ones on the map have actually been rebuilt. This is very tangible evidence of the control and influence these two policies had over the region and how the way of life for many Tibetans changed and how the effects can still be seen today.

title: Communist Control
desc:
Few believe that the Chinese Communist Party’s strategy for Tibet is working today. The economic development and political repression China that have been pressed upon the Tibetan people were meant to reconcile Tibetans to Chinese rule and to make them abandon their loyalty to the Dalai Lama. These policies, much to Chinese dismay, had the opposite effect. Immolation is mainly meant to call for the Dalai Lama’s homecoming.

The immolations and other forms of protest are easily contained because of the heavy Chinese police presence and the Dalai Lama’s commitment to non-violence. Not only is there an existence of the Chinese military in Tibet, but also the Chinese police are also overwhelming present in everyday life. The military play a larger role in the administration of Tibet than any other Chinese province. No Tibetan serves in the leadership of the military district governing Tibet.

Human rights conditions in Tibet remain dismal. Under the Chinese occupation, the Tibetan people are denied most rights guaranteed in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights including the rights to self-determination, freedom of speech, assembly, movement, expression and travel. This information shows the little to no progress that Tibetans have made to free themselves from the strict rule of the Chinese. 

How Do Tibetans Protest?

  1. Tibetan Uprising day: Protests often take place around Tibetan National  Uprising Day on March 10th. The day commemorates China’s suppressing starting in 1959. 
  2. Non-Violence: Most of the Tibetan protests are peaceful. They are mostly non-violent to follow the path of the Dalai Lama. 
  3. New forms of protest: In 2013 Tibetans were ordered to fly Chinese flags in their homes. In response to this, many Tibetans gathered to throw the flags in the river. 
  4. Everyday resistance: Many of these forms of resistance are subtle. Some pray on the anniversary of Tibetan National Uprising Day, others secretly carry pictures of the Dalai Lama, and many join together to promote Tibetan culture and support Tibetan businesses.  

Self-immolation

Starting in 2009, Tibetans have begun self-immolating in response to the Chinese Rule. The peak of these protests was in 2012, when more than 80 took place. Students, teachers, mothers, fathers, and even children have self-immolated. The map on the left shows where these have occurred in China and Tibet. The larger the dot, the more self-immolations at that location. Clicking on a dot will show the people who self-immolated.

The Dalai Lama's response to the self-immolations

The Dalai Lama has been criticized for not condemning self-immolations in Tibet. He refuses to do so out of respect for the families of those who have self-immolated. He has stated that he does not want to bring shame to the family, or say that their loved one died doing something wrong.

title: Dalai Lama
desc:
Since the Chinese invasion, the Dalai Lama has taken several actions in hopes of establishing an autonomous Tibetan state within the People’s Republic of China. He has also taken steps towards finding a peaceful resolution to the Chinese occupation of Tibet. 

In 1963, he issued a draft constitution for Tibet containing a number of reforms to democratize the government. This was called the Charter of Tibetans in Exile. It intended to grant freedom of speech, belief, assembly, and movement. In addition, it provided detailed guidelines for Tibetans living in exile. In September of 1987, the Dalai Lama proposed the Five Points Peace Plan. It was the first step in a peaceful solution to the Chinese government influence and hoped to end violence. 

On June 15, 1988, the Lama addressed members on the European Parliament in France. There, he proposed talks between the Chinese and Tibetans that would lead to a self-governing democratic political entity for Tibet. The plan was later thrown out because the Chinese leadership had a negative reaction towards it.

However, as the Dalai Lama grows older, there has been much confusion and speculation about to what will happen when he dies. 

The line of succession: 

In 1995, six-year-old Gedhun Choekyi Nyima, was named the 11th Panchen Lama—one of the highest ranking religious officials in Tibet as a part of the Gelug tradition. The Panchen Lama bears part of the responsibility of finding the reincarnation of the Dalai Lama, and vice versa. This has been the tradition since the 5th Dalai Lama recognized Lobsang Chökyi Gyaltsen as the Panchen Lama of Tashi Lhunpo.

Shortly after Gedhun was discovered, the child and his family were abducted by the Chinese government. Six months later, China announced that it had selected a Tibetan boy named Gyaltsen Norbu to become the Panchen Lama. Gedhun Choekyi Nyima and his family have not been seen since, and according to Norbu Dunzhub, a member of the Tibet Autonomous Region’s United Front Work Department, “The reincarnated child Panchen Lama...is being educated, living a normal life, growing up healthily and does not wish to be disturbed."

In response to this, the Dalai Lama has stated that he may not reincarnate again, and that the line of succession may be broken. He has also considered choosing his next successor while he is still alive—through either a democratic election by senior monks, or by choosing the successor himself.

title: Tibet Today
desc:
Immigration

At the end of the 20th century, China launched the “Developing West” campaign—a long term project to promote social and economic integration between China and its western regions. The “west” in China includes the 5 autonomous regions of Tibet, Xinjiang, Inner Mongolia, Ningxia, Guangxi. Among these regions, the Tibet Autonomous Region (TAR) has been a priority. 

In an effort to promote this “integration,” Chinese economic policies have encouraged the migration of Han Chinese into Tibet—a migration that is often seen as a second invasion. One way in which China has facilitated the migration of the Han Chinese has been with the construction of the Qinghai Tibet Railway—an express train that runs from Beijing to Lhasa and finished construction in July of 2006.

 

According to Tibetan exiles, the region is currently home to 7.5 million Han Chinese and only 6 million Tibetans. However, according to data from PRC 2000 Census, the numbers are very different. It is difficult to get verified data on the populations of this region. However, in more urbanized areas, such as Lhasa, it is clear that the number of Han Chinese has risen dramatically since the end of the 20th century.

How Han Chinese migration has changed daily life in Tibet:

  1. The Tibetan language is mainly used in Tibetan Language class. One must know Chinese in order to survive. Half of all teachers are Chinese, and all exams, except the Tibetan Language exam, are in Chinese. According to Tendun, a 23-year-old monk, “You have to learn Chinese as without it you can’t achieve anything and you’ll have no future.” 
  2. Diets are changing. Tibetan children who are sent to boarding school where they learn to like rice, instead of Tsampa—traditional roasted barley. According to Luorong Zhandui, an ethnic Tibetan, “They [the children] come home, and they don’t want tsampa, which makes parents worry they are losing their identity.” Additionally, there has been an increase in Chinese cuisine and restaurants found in Tibetan.
  3. China has invested huge amounts of money urbanizing and building up the infrastructure in Tibet. This includes the construction of 230,000 grey, stone houses for 1.3 million Tibetans. This, in conjunction with the express train, has been used to facilitate tourism as many Tibetans have been forced to move away from tourist-areas in Tibet, and into these “comfort houses.”

Tourism

After decades of systematically oppressing Tibetan culture, China has realized that it has great financial value. Today, Tibet is being marketed, especially to domestic Chinese tourists, as an attractive holiday destination. Critics say that tourism is being used to bind Tibet more closely to China. Additionally, the Tibet seen by tourists has been sanitized by and for the Chinese—the guides are Chinese and the food is Chinese.


According to numbers published by the Chinese government, about 23 million tourists visit Tibet a year. However, it is possible that this number could be as low as 8 million. Nevertheless, this influx of tourists can be seen as an attempt by China to trivialize and commodify Tibetan culture. 


“She is Crying on the Hill,” a blog post by a Chinese traveler named “December,” presents and comments on images of other Chinese tourists photographing Tibetans at the Taktsang Lhamo temple in a highly intrusive and aggressive manner. Additionally, there has been controversy over photos emerging of Chinese tourists standing on traditional Tibetan prayer flags or sitting on Buddhist statues.

title: The Indian Diaspora
desc:
Gonkar Gyatso's third photograph depicts an impression of a Tibetan refugee in India, which is home to more Tibetan refugees than anywhere else in the world.  Through the composition of the photo, he is able to depict the importance Tibetan refugees attribute to their heritage and Buddhism despite the unstable lifestyle that has been forced upon them.

Painting of the Potala

Serving as the Dalai Lama's winter palace, the Potala stands atop the mountainous Tibetan skyline.  More importantly, it stands as an icon of Tibetan history, a vital and holy relic in Tibetan Buddhism, and a symbol of the Tibetan homeland for refugees across the world.  Because of its prominence in Tibetan culture and consciousness, it is no wonder Gonkar Gyatso places it in front of him as he sits in traditional robes.  Another important feature is the 14th Dalai Lama residing in the heavens above it, as he is another holy symbol of connection to Tibet for many refugees.

Tin Walls       

Gonkar Gyatso resides in what is made to be a very make-shift shelter.  Not only does this depict some of the living situations for Tibetan refugees in India, but it could also be interpreted as a symbol of hopeful impermanence--that one day Tibetans will be able to return home.

Clothing & Hair

Like the photo referencing Chinese culture, Gonkar's clothing is striking in its cultural meaning.  He is wearing the red robes worn by Buddhist lay practitioners across Tibet.  His long hair is also not an unusual length for Tibetans, but unlike the first photo, it appears much less maintained.  This could be referencing the alternate lifestyle refugees experience in India without letting go of their heritage.

Furniture

The black chest is still present, but it is covered up by a sign that reads "Bangla."  This is an Indian beer (notice the 5.5% vol text on the bottom), so the fact it is covering the common object in each painting could mean that Indian culture is somehow affecting, perhaps obscuring Tibetan culture.  There is no doubt that the two cultures are interacting like never before, but the implications and the opinions regarding the interactions are mixed and uncertain.

Suitcases & Picture of 14th Dalai Lama

Like the tin walls, the suitcases are a direct reference to travel and impermanence.  Though Tibetan refugees have been in India for several decades, there is always the chance they will have to leave to move elsewhere, maybe back to Tibet.  The picture of the Dalai Lama restates his importance as a rallying figure for the refugee population.  Through all this hardship, he is a symbol of love, faith, and home that refugees across the world use to maintain their Tibetan identity.

title: Demography
desc:
The Tibetan Diaspora into India

After a failed uprising against China in 1959, many Tibetans (including the 14th Dalai Lama) fled Tibet. Groups of people from all three regions of Tibet (Kham, Utsang, and Amdo) fled to various parts of the world, but the vast majority settled in India. After decades of fluctuating population movements, there are different estimates of how many Tibetan refugees reside in India that range from 90,000 to 150,000. Our statistics rely on the higher estimates based off a 2012 article by Ahmad Javeed.

Click through the visualization to explore the Tibetan population within each refugee camp throughout India. Scroll below to see a firsthand look various Tibet refugee camps in India.

India, Nepal, & Bhutan

After the Exodus in 1959, Tibetans found their way into three neighboring countries: India, Nepal, & Butan.  Refugees stayed in each country for multiple decades, but in the 1980s, all three reassessed their acceptance of Tibetan refugees.  Nepal began to refuse to process immigration paperwork and also deported many refugees back to Tibet.  Bhutan demanded that Tibetan and Nepalese immigrants assimilate, so those who refused were forced to leave and generally went to India. 

In general, India has continued to be welcoming and accommodating, but in the 1980s, the immigration processing became much more complicated.  Refugees who were in India before 1987 maintained their immigrant status, but those who have come after 1987 have had to endure a lot more processing time and effort to receive "Registration Certificates."  In 2003, India also began denying sanctuary to "political prisoners," so the CTA has had to intervene and relocate Tibetans of this status, most often to Australia.

Though India has been a relatively welcoming government and society given the situation, Tibetan refugees cannot get work permits, rent apartments, or open a bank account.  They also have no right to protest or assembly, which became problematic during a Tibetan protest in New Delhi that resulted in self-immolation and mass arrests.  Besides protesting, many Tibetans in India fear arrest and deportation because of the more complicated nature of the immigrant processing as well as stigma from Indian citizens because of increased job competition and resource scarcity.

Dharamsala as "Little Lhasa" 

Dharamsala became home to many Tibetans, but it also became the seat of the Tibetan Government in exile created by the 14th Dalai Lama, also known as the Central Tibetan Administration (CTA). While Dharamsala is not home to the most Tibetan refugees in India, it has garnered the title, ""Little Lhasa"" due to the CTA's presence, as well as its major cultural, educational and religious features.

title: The Dalai Lama
desc:
The Dalai Lama Click play(here,665,682,,5) to show his journey on the map.

The 14th Dalai Lama's Flight From Lhasa

During the Chinese invasion in 1950, the 14th Dalai Lama's advisors recalled an ancient prophecy that foretold the line of the Dalai Lamas ending with the 13th. The 14th Dalai Lama was only 15 at the time. Fearing this prophecy to be true, the oracles advised that he be instated at once, as opposed to waiting until the age of 18 as most Dalai Lamas do. 

The following year, Tibetan streets were filled with armed rebels opposing the Chinese occupation. Chinese forces and Tibetan supporters of the Dalai Lama found themselves in constant conflict. 

In March of 1959, the Dalai Lama was invited by Chinese officials to a theatrical performance in lieu of a religious celebration in Lhasa. Asked to come alone, the Dalai Lama's advisors suspected danger, and crowds of Tibetans surrounded the Norbulingka Palace to protect him. 

On the 17th of that month, the Dalai Lama fled Lhasa dressed as a Tibetan soldier, armed with a rifle. His officials and family also fled Lhasa and began the trek to India.

It was only after this journey that the Dalai Lama set up the Government of Tibet in Exile in Dharamsala, and settled around 80,000 Tibetan exiles in agricultural occupations. Dharamsala quickly became known as "Little Lhasa", and a safe haven for Tibetan refugees.
