title: Education and Culture
desc:
Tibetan Temples and Monasteries in India

 Buddhist monasteries are considered to be some of the most holy and sacred places in India. While more than 80% of the Indian population identifies with the Hindu Faith, Tibetan refugees have managed to maintain their spiritual identities through the construction of traditional Tibetan Buddhist monasteries in their relocated communities. One of the most famous of these monasteries is the Namgyal Monastery (identified in white) which is associated with the Dalai Lamas and located prominently in Dharamsala. It has since become a major tourist attraction and hosts frequent teachings when the 14th Dalai Lama is in Dharamsala.

 Buddhist temples are also fundamental in Tibetan societies, and are distinct from monasteries as places of worship as opposed to religious residential and educational spaces. These temples have allowed Tibetan communities to practice their faith freely and celebrate their Buddhist values.

Tibetan Schools in India

 Before the exile from Tibet, the literacy rate among Tibetans was incredibly low. However, thanks to the Dalai Lama's foresight and the collaboration with the then-Indian prime minister, separate Tibetan schools were established within the Indian education system.

Maintaining Culture through Education

Today, Tibetan literacy in India is as high as 82.4% and the Central Tibetan Schools Administration has facilitated in the creation of 71 schools which educate more than 10,000 Tibetan students. One of the most well-known of these schools is the Tibetan Children's Village, located in Dharamsala in the northeast of India.

Additionally, exile has forced Tibetans to constantly evaluate their personal identities away from their homeland, juggle the pressures of modern life, and decide as a culture what it means to be Tibetan.  One way of doing this has been by means of the school curriculum in which Tibetan children learn about Tibetan history, their homeland (through modern mapping techniques), the Dalai Lama, as well as things like traditional clothing and rituals. Because it is from a Tibetan perspective, this is one vital way the Tibetan Government in exile has been able to subvert the Chinese attempts to assimilate Tibet. 

Besides formal K-12 schooling, the CTA also founded and manages the link(Tibetan Institute for Performing Arts,http://tipa.asia/about/mission-statement). Music and dance is another arena in which modernity and cultural transmission can dilute certain styles and traditions.  TIPA also features productions that pay homage to Indian cultures, but TIPA is one of the primary institutions designed to preserve and continue the musical features of Tibetan heritage, including:

Ache Lhamo (Tibetan opera)

Dances from various regions of Tibet (the video features a dance from Central Tibet)

A Ka Ma Band (a fusion of contemporary and traditional folk styles from Tibet and the Diaspora that originated in the 1980s)

Tibetan Children's Village

Another way the Dalai Lama and the Government in exile have attempted to preserve culture and the safety of Tibetan people has been by offering childcare and education through the link(Tibetan Children's Village,http://tcv.org.in/content/tcvs-mission). The first was founded in 1960 by the Dalai Lama as a response to more and more refugee children arriving in India ill and malnourished.  The network has expanded over decades to encompass various residential schools, day schools, and vocational training across India.  Not only does this institution help maintain cultural heritage, but it also offers relief for refugee parents.

Higher Education

The link(The Dalai Lama Institute for Higher Education,https://www.dalailamainstitute.edu.in) is the latest innovation of the Tibetan Children's Village in an effort to provide higher education.  They offer Bachelor's degrees in Tibetan & Chinese Languages, Commerce, Computer Applications, Economics, History, Politics, English, Journalism, and Psychology.  They also have a Ph.D program in Tibetan Studies.  It also appears to be relatively accessible, as all TCV students are eligible for full scholarships. This effort can be seen as a response of the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to the rapidly modernizing and globalizing society they have found themselves in.  

Another major source of higher education for Tibetan refugees is the link(Central University of Tibetan Studies,http://www.cuts.ac.in/). This University offers studies in Buddhist philosophies including the Sakya School, the Nyingma School, the Gelug School, and the Kargyud School.  It also offers studies in the pre-Buddhist religion of Tibet, commonly referred to as Bon.  Additionally, there are studies offered for various social sciences, languages, education, traditional Tibetan art, Tibetan medicine (with its foundation in Bon), and Astrological sciences called Bhot Jyotish Vidya.  Once again, the educational structure for Tibetans in exile features traditional and modern topics to renegotiate Tibetan identity away from home.

Literary Preservation

The Tibetan literary canon was once one of the most expansive in the world.  Once the Tibetan writing system was created, the many monks/nuns and monasteries in Tibet dedicated themselves to recording historical and religious teachings.  However, when China came and destroyed monasteries across Tibet, many literary works were lost.

When fleeing, Tibetans clamored to keep some of their cultural literature and brought a hefty amount to India.  This is where, in 1965, an American scholar named E. Gene Smith encountered Tibetan refugees and learned under various lamas.  Through this effort, he was able to maintain original pieces of Tibetan literature with the Library of Congress in the U.S.  He also spent over two decades making copies of Tibetan works for further dissemination. 

During this time, he was able to take advantage of U.S. link(Public Law 480,http://www.merip.org/mer/mer145/public-law-480-better-bomber), which "enables food-deficit 'friendly countries' to purchase US agricultural commodities with local currency, thus saving foreign exchange reserves and relieving US grain surpluses."  This money was then invested in the preservation of Tibetan works.  In 1999, Smith founded the Tibetan Buddhist Resource Center, which was expanded and renamed the link(Buddhist Digital Resource Center,https://www.tbrc.org/#!footer/about/missionhistory). This organization has "located, digitized, cataloged, and archived over 13.5 million pages of culturally significant Buddhist works" in order to ensure they remain open to the public.

Alongside these efforts, the 14th Dalai Lama founded the link(Library of Tibetan Works and Archives,http://tibetanlibrary.org/history-of-ltwa) in 1970. Not only is this institution dedicated to preserving and disseminating Tibetan and Buddhist texts across the world, but it also offers classes in Tibetan language and religious practices in India.

title: Tibetan Government in Exile
desc: pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4552/38722167371_1e7581b15c_o_d.jpg)On March 17, 1959 the 14th Dalai Lama fled his residence in Lhasa, Tibet. The escape of the Dalai Lama stemmed from age long conflict with the Chinese government regarding their claim to the Tibetan territories. The controversy came to the point where the Dalai Lama’ safety was in direct harm leading him to flee his homeland and thus change the landscape of the Tibetan government.  page() pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4520/38722161311_a6343b7a27_o_d.png)Up until the Dalai Lama’s exile in 1959, Tibet recognized itself as an independent sovereignty. Before the exile, The Ganden Phodrang was the Tibetan government originally set up by the 5th Dalai in 1642. The government towards the 1940’s was organized in which the Dalai Lama was the lead executive power within the government and then under him was the Kashag governing council. The Kashag was comprised to be the Dalai Lama’s most trusted advisors as the council was divided into “representatives” from seven different divisions: political, military, economic, judicial, foreign, financial, and educational departments. Click zoomer(here ,https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4520/38722161311_a6343b7a27_o_d.png) for a zoomable image. page() pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4546/38722163211_97df79da33_z_d.jpg)Upon fleeing from Lhasa, the Dalai Lama eventually settled in Dharamsala, India where he established a government originally called the Tibetan Kashag government in 1960, and then eventually taking form into the present day Central Tibetan Administration (CTA). The new government was intended to be the governing body of all exiled Tibetans throughout India and the entire world, its purpose was stated as it was “not designed to take power in Tibet” and would be dissolved “as soon as freedom is restored in Tibet.” This new government started from humble beginnings of an initial capital of what equates to $1,120 USD. Recognizing that the Tibetan exile would take place over a long duration, the Dalai Lama began to take a more western, democratic approach towards his governmental approach. On Sept. 2 1960, democratic steps were taken when the Tibetan Parliament in Exile came into existence. In this Tibetan Parliament, candidates were nominated by the exiled citizens and then later voted on. In 1990, the Dalai Lama increased the number of Parliament members to its present day amount of 46.  page()pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4519/24849412788_e36937e055_o_d.jpg)While in Dharamsala the CTA began to continually progress. In June 1991, a constitution was drafted called “The Charter of Tibetans in Exile”. This 26-page document laid out the policies and structures the CTA was to follow moving forward. The charter encompasses the universal Declaration of Human Rights specified by the UN, while also ensuring that all Tibetans have equal treatment and freedoms under law regardless of gender, age, religion, or origin. Another key distinction within the created within the charter was the separation of power within the government into three branches: executive, legislative, and judicial. As within the government before the exile, the Dalai Lama was designated with the executive power, the highest authority within the government. The legislative authority was then vested in the newly created Tibetan Parliament. The CTA effectively was divided into seven departments, similar to the format of the government during the later Ganden Phodrang time period back in Lhasa. The divisions were Religion & Culture, Home, Finance, Education, Security, International Relations, and Health; each performing separate tasks and functions to ensure the longevity of this community in exile. “The Charter of Tibetans in Exile” is what the CTA operates under even till today. There were still changes made throughout time as we see the Tibetan government morph towards implementing Western ideals into their governing structure. page() pic(https://farm5.staticflickr.com/4581/38722162141_92732e3045_z_d.jpg)In 2001, we saw an unprecedented move as the Dalai Lama proposed that the executive authority within the government be split between himself and another individual, for the first time in history. Soon after this proposal was accepted, we saw the first democratic election take place amongst Tibetan exile voters to nominate who would share the executive power with the Dalai Lama. The sharing of power continued for another ten years before eventually evolving into its present day democratic power structure. In 2011, the Dalai Lama himself petitioned a proposal where he would be relinquished of his formal authority within the government and a newly elected official would hold the executive office. The petition was eventually voted on and approved, and in May 2011 the Tibetan exile voters elected their new Sikyong (president), Lobsang Sangay. Many viewed the relinquishing of power from the Dalai Lama concerning but he states, “My desire to devolve authority has nothing to do with a wish to shirk responsibility,” he said, according to a prepared text of his speech. “It is to benefit Tibetans in the long run.” The shift in government authority from the Dalai Lama to an elected official can be seen as an attempt to align the Tibetan government with Western ideologies and influence.

title: The World Diaspora
desc:
At the close of the 1980s and the First Wave of the Tibetan diaspora, a new generation of transplants began to disperse further outward from India. Due in part to a newly developed public interest in Tibet and the human rights issues surrounding the Chinese occupation, as well as a growing number of foreign government assistance and various charities, assistance programs, and humanitarian aid, there was now not only incentive for Tibetans to move outside of Asia, but also the means to do so.

This Second Wave of the diaspora brought Tibetans in direct contact with the Western world and its culture on a large scale for the first time. With refugees beginning to settle not only in Western Asia and Europe, but North America as well, these previously traditionally-minded Tibetans began to develop lives of their own in their new host nations.

Some resisted the culture of their new homes, choosing to forge small, tight-knit communities in order to insulate themselves from the creeping influence of Western society. Others chose to fully assimilate, integrating themselves completely into whatever nation chose to adopt and shelter them. And others still chose to adopt a more cooperative perspective on their situation, creating unique, hybrid societies which combined their cultures with that of their new environments.

Through this period, an entirely new subset of Tibetan identity began to emerge, one that reflected not only the traditions and customs of old Tibet, but also the influences that the Western world began to have on these newly-displaced peoples. This new wave of Tibetan immigrants and refugees struggled to continue the ways of their homeland, while still adapting and surviving in their new homes.

About Identity 4

This conflict of identity is represented in full by the 4th photo in Gonkar Gyatso’s “My Identity” series, which depicts a modern-day Tibetan citizen of the Global Diaspora, attempting to reconcile his Tibetan heritage with a contemporary and Western setting. The figure sits in a very modern, Western-looking room, with nearly no sign of the Tibetan accents that adorned the previous photos. However, despite this non-traditional, non-Tibetan environment, the figure, Gonkar himself, still shows signs of his heritage. His tattoo is in traditional Tibetan script, and his painting is a highly stylized version of a Tibetan mandala, used in religious rituals. Although the figure is clearly no longer in Tibet, he still seeks to represent and practice his cultural traditions, which is why the painting is the perfect representation for those who relocated during the World Diaspora.

title: Demography
desc:
The Global wave of the Tibetan Diaspora saw Tibetans leaving their homes in not only Tibet, but India and Nepal as well, in order to seek new homes all over the world. According to a census in 1998, by the Central Tibetan Administration (CTA) in Dharamsala, the number of Tibetans (both in nationality and ancestry) living throughout the world is around 120,000.

Click a country on the map to learn some specific historical and demographic information for each, or read below for a general overview of each continental region.

Note that population data is often conflicting, and the numbers presented may not represent current population estimates.

South Asia

The first area settled by those in this Global wave of the Tibetan Diaspora was South Asia, simply due to proximity and ease of access for those initially leaving Tibet. The CTA lists 52 different Tibetan refugee settlements in the region, with most located in India, Nepal, and Bhutan. Many others also live in other large cities which host others of differing nationalities (the CTA only tracks settlements of predominantly Tibetan peoples). These 52 settlements tend to adhere closely to Tibetan customs and traditions, often with a monastery or some other religious body as the center of the community, both geographically and culturally. The South Asia region is also the most actively changing in terms of the motion of Tibetans peoples in and out when compared to other regions, with many young students moving for education, and older demographics moving for religious purposes.

Europe

Many of those who did not settle permanently in South Asia instead moved outward, into the Western Hemisphere, a process which started in the 1960s. Switzerland was one of the first nations to allow Tibetan refugees to settle within its borders (with an initial wave of around 1500), with other Scandinavian nations quickly following suit, albeit in much smaller numbers (with a little over 100 living there now). The rest of Europe allowed for the immigration of Tibetan refugees soon after, with around 640 Tibetans living throughout Europe today.

Click the "Interactions with the Western World" section for more specific information on Tibetans in Switzerland.

North America

After the relative success of the Swiss relocation of Tibetan refugees in the 1960s, the Dalai Lama began negotiations with the Canadian and American governments in the 70s for similar arrangements. While the United States remained initially uncooperative, the Canadian government allowed for around 200 Tibetans, mostly from India and Nepal, to enter the country early in the 1970s. The first official wave of immigrants to the United States would not occur until the 1990s, although scattered groups arrived in small numbers before then. Canada now hosts a Tibetan population of around 5,000, with the United States hosting just above 11,000.

For more information on Tibetans in Canada and the United States, click the “Interactions with the Western World” section of the timeline.

Rather, they have slowly trickled into the United Kingdom over a series of decades, with many arriving, historically, with the help of various sponsors and charity organizations.

Following an increased public interest in Tibet and its culture in the 60s and 70s, particularly in Tibetan Buddhism, several Non-Governmental Organizations were established, which further established ties with displaced Tibetans, allowing hundreds more to arrive during the later decades of the 20th century.

title: Interactions with the Western world
desc:
Tibetan interaction with the Western world, at least in the form of refugee asylum and immigration, did not really begin until the early 1970s, after the passing of various resettlement initiatives. The U.S. was the last to open its borders. Although Tibetans have integrated themselves fairly well within these nations, the adjustment to a near-opposite lifestyle is not easy, and many still face political and social challenges even today.


(a Europeans for Tibet solidarity rally in 2012)

Struggle with National Identity

One of the most pressing and controversial issues facing Tibetans in the Western world in the 21st century is the fact that many of their host governments in the West are refusing to recognize them as such. Despite the fact that the vast majority of these Tibetan transplants fled their homes due to pressures created by the Chinese occupation of Tibet, several western nations, such as the United States and Switzerland, are now forcing Tibetan nationals to identify in official government documents and census materials as Chinese in ethnicity.

This is due to a variety of reasons, predominately that most Western countries tend to have at least some sort of friendly relationship with China, at least economically, with the United States in particular not willing to do much to antagonize one of their closest trading partners. And since China does not recognize Tibet as a separate, sovereign nation, nor do their allies tend to do any differently. Also, from a purely logistical standpoint, it is much easier for governments to group Tibetans in with the Chinese, considering that, technically speaking, Tibet is, in fact, a Chinese-controlled territory.

And in the case of Switzerland, and many other European nations, the rising anti-immigrant sentiments in the public eye are making it more and more difficult to give Tibetans special treatment with refugee status. The impact of these policies is the unfortunate loss of any official recognition from host governments of a real difference between Tibetans and Chinese, which, to those who fled specifically to escape Chinese influence on their lives, is a massive blow to their cultural identity.

To navigate through this map, click on the starred countries to get more specifics about their relationship with Tibetan refugees. The cities also marked as a star are explored in the same level of detail. For all the rest, a click on the dot will bring up a quick overview.

title: Tibetans in Swizterland
desc:
Tibetans in Switzerland

History:

In the 1960s, following the political upheaval in Tibet, the Dalai Lama attempted to appeal to the international community for places of refuge in which displaced Tibetans could resettle. Switzerland was one of the first nations to offer support, with the Swiss Red Cross taking full responsibility of the endeavor from the government. About 100 officially arrived in 1964, following the earlier settlement of six smaller Tibetan communities in eastern Switzerland, mostly in small villages. As of this time, there were around 300 resettled Tibetans in the mountainous nation, along with around 150 orphaned Tibetans who had been adopted by Swiss families. Andy by the end of the 1960s, there were over 1,000. Today, around 4,000 Tibetans reportedly call Switzerland home (official sources are somewhat contradictory), making it the largest concentration of Tibetans in Europe.


(the Rikon monastery)

The Tibetans who arrived during the first initial wave into Switzerland had a relatively easy time acclimating to their new environment. They were housed in communities specifically designed to aide them in preserving their customs, and even had a monastery built for them in the village of Rikon. Geographically, the Swiss landscape was not much different than their own, so there was a familiarity in their surroundings that helped to ease the transition, which is the featured picture.

In fact, the notion that the Tibetans were “mountainous people” was one of the main reasons that the Swiss accepted them with such open arms, as they felt a kinship in their similar, elevated upbringings. The Swiss people were also no friends to the Communists, particularly the Chinese, so they were especially sympathetic to the political turmoil in Tibet.

The original Tibetans who arrived in Switzerland did not have much difficulty finding employment, either. Men worked in textile mills, or as carpenters, gardeners, groundskeepers, or general day laborers. Women found jobs in gardens, but also as housekeepers and tailors. Swiss employers at the time noted that the Tibetans under their employ were extremely fast learners, and excellent workers, despite somewhat of a language barrier. In the smaller communities, income and earnings would go into a communal pool, which would then be equally distributed, with slightly more being paid to the men than the women.

Difficulties

Like many other areas in the Western World settled by Tibetans, those in Switzerland initially faced an enormous language barrier, as they knew neither Swiss nor German, nor did the Swiss know any Tibetan. This continues to be a problem for new arrivals even today. However, the largest issue facing modern day Swiss-Tibetans has to do with the official recognition of their nationality. In July of 2016, following policy changes within the Swiss government, the Tibetans living in Switzerland were suddenly faced with a drastic change: They must now identify as Chinese, rather than Tibetan.
(from The Guardian: Tibetan and Swiss nationals protesting against a visit from the Chinese President in January 2017)

As a result, Tibetans are finding it more and more difficult to get official recognition as a refugee. This change is due to multiple factors, predominantly of which are the newly conservative immigration attitudes that are on the rise in Europe, and the relaxation of animosity towards China, for economic purposes. For Tibetans who fled specifically because of Chinese political pressures to preserve their Tibetan identities, these policy changes have almost completely undermined their efforts, and have been an enormous blow to their cultural identity.

Click on another city or country to compare their resettlement policy and strategies.

title: Tibetans in Canada
desc:
(then Canadian Prime Minister Stephen Harper with the Dalai Lama)

History:

While Canada’s first interactions with Tibet actually began in the late 1800s, with several missionary trips to the country by Canadian religious scholars, the first Tibetan citizens didn’t arrive in Canada until the 1970s. In the decade prior, at the height of the unrest in Tibet caused by the Chinese occupation, the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) approached the Canadian government about allowing a small number of refugees settle in Ottawa, as the agricultural land their matched what they were used to in Tibet.

After several years of internal debate and uncooperative resistance from the Canadian government, an agreement was finally reached in which 228 Tibetan refugees were allowed entrance into the country in 1971. These refugees were settled in Ontario, Quebec, Alberta and Manitoba, and it was decided that the possibility of future Tibetans being accepted into the country would be determined by the success of this first batch.

For a much more in-depth look at the history of Tibetans in Canada, click link(here,http://tibet.ca/en/tibet_and_canada/tibetans_in_canada)

Difficulties Adapting

These original 228 Tibetan refugees were carefully selected, with favoritism shown for those who were single and of working age, or relatively young, married couples, so many others were skipped over and left behind. The Canadian government also collaborated with the Dalai Lama, who specifically chose refugees representing the four schools of Tibetan Buddhism.

Because the Tibetans were immediately scattered throughout 11 different areas in various Canadian provinces, forging communities with one another was nearly impossible. They also faced a massive language barrier, with no knowledge whatsoever of either English or French.


(the Tibetan Canadian Cultural Centre Opera Group)


However, within three years, nearly all 228 of these Tibetan refugees, who came to the country with nothing, had become not only gainfully employed, but had established homes and lives for themselves. It is at this point that small, tight-knit communities began to develop, with three areas in particular serving as hubs of Tibetan culture: Ontario, British Columbia, and most notably, Toronto.

Click one of the three Canadian cities on the map to learn more about the Tibetan Communities they each host.

title: Tibetans in British Columbia
desc:
pic(http://www.tcsofbc.org/files/cache/f6e2713bd50eccb6febccbd96fe8b536.jpeg) The first wave of Tibetan refugees arrived in British Columbia in 1971, the same year as the Canadian government’s resettlement of other Tibetans in various regions of Canada, albeit they themselves were not part of that same program. The region has had close ties with the Dalai Lama himself, who visited in 1980, 1993, and 2004, where he received an honorary doctorate from two universities, including the University of British Columbia.The general consensus among Tibetan transplants in the province of British Columbia is that they were, as a whole, accepted with open arms by the Canadians who call the area home. The geographical similarities to Tibet have also been noted as an incentive for settlement in the area.page()

pic(https://i.ytimg.com/vi/6IzCDLlJ__w/maxresdefault.jpg) Like many other major areas of Tibetan settlement in the West, British Columbia is home to its own Tibetan community group, the aptly-named Tibetan Cultural Society of British Columbia. Created in 1981, the group services the Greater Vancouver area, and, like many other similar groups, seeks to “promote and preserve Tibetan Culture and Heritage.” They place a particular emphasis on educating those generations who were born in Canada, as opposed to Tibet, on their people’s customs, beliefs, and rituals. They also help new arrivals settle in the area, and were partially responsible for organizing the past visits from the Dalai Lama.page()

pic(https://kagyumonlamnorthamerica.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/20110622-kagyu-monlam-4634.jpg) In the coastal city of Richmond, British Columbia, the first Canadian traditional Tibetan Monastery. Opened in 2010 by Thrangu Rinpoche, a prominent figure in the Kagyu school of Tibetan Buddhism, the monastery is designed to be a destination for those in the west seeking to experience teachings of Buddhism in an extremely authentic environment. The monastery boasts elaborately adorned walls and halls, with depictions of various deities and teachers decorating nearly every available surface. It is one of many Thrangu establishments worldwide, with this particular monastery headed by resident lama Lama Pema Tsewang.

title: Tibetans in Ontario
desc:
pic(http://farm7.static.flickr.com/6016/6019448802_5f053dea77.jpg) As one of the original sites of Tibetan settlement in Canada, the province of Ontario (with the exception of Toronto) has a small, but thriving Tibetan community. In 1971, 100 Tibetans, who had been living in exile in India since the early 1960s, were granted asylum in Ontario. This initial 100 were settled into the cities of Belleville, Lindsay, and Cobourg, in small family units, with nine, six, and four families in each city, respectively.page()

pic(https://sftcanada.files.wordpress.com/2008/03/_3211369.jpg) This small group of Tibetan transplants was determined to keep the customs and practices of their homeland alive, and were aware of the need for an organizational structure to do so. So, in 1980, they created the Canadian Tibetan Association of Ontario, which to this day oversees much of the Canadian Tibetan community in organizing cultural events, educating newer generations on Tibetan history and customs, and generally keeping the Tibetans of Canada unified.

title: The Tibetan Community in Toronto
desc:
Toronto is home to not only the largest community of Tibetans in Canada, but in the entirety of North America. In the neighborhood of Parkdale, in Toronto’s west end, lies an area that has come to be known internationally as “Little Tibet.” This unique neighborhood is home to over 1700 Tibetans, many of whom have arrived only within the last decade or so.

Given that around 3000 Tibetans live in Toronto as a whole, Parkdale certainly hosts the highest concentration of displaced Tibetans. And this number is expected to grow exponentially, with projections reaching the 10,000 mark within a decade.

So why have so many Tibetans recently chosen to settle in this relatively small, unassuming neighborhood in Toronto? Simply put, because the sheer number makes it seem so much like home for newcomers. The primary language spoken here is still Tibetan, and much of the country’s cultural, religious, and social practices are still observed here, making its nickname of Little Tibet all the more accurate. The small neighborhood is such an insulating, preserving force for the Tibetan way of life that some residents even claim that Tibetan culture will soon exist in a more pure form here than in Tibet itself.

Economy

Being such a haven for Tibetan peoples and their culture, Parkdale is also, naturally, home to an entire micro-economy hosting a wide range of Tibetan businesses. Residents have established restaurants, which serve traditional Tibetan cuisine, shops selling craft supplies and various religious paraphernalia, and even prayer and language centers, to both help new arrivals adapt, while still being able to practice the traditions they grew up with. See the map for a short video tour of the area by a resident, showing a few of the Tibetan-owned businesses in the area.

Community

Additionally, numerous community centers have been set up, which cater to not only the neighborhood’s youth, but also to its older citizens as well. These centers help recent immigrants settle in, and provide services such as transportation and job assistance for those who have not yet been able to quite plant their roots. They also host a multitude of cultural events, ranging from traditional Tibetan festivals and rituals, to educational seminars designed to teach those born in Canada about their ancestral home.

Below is a video showing one of these community centers celebrating the birthday of the Dalai Lama.

title: Tibetans in the United States
desc:
History

Interaction between Tibet and the United States was virtually nonexistent before the latter half of the 20th century. Although there were infrequent, scattered cases of individual Tibetans entering the US beforehand, with some arriving as early as the 1890s, the vast majority did not arrive until the height of the Tibetan Diaspora. Despite negotiations taking place between the Dalai Lama and the United States government in 1970s, a real, serious attempt to resettle Tibetan refugees in any considerable numbers did not occur until the 1990s.

The Immigration Act of 1990 finally allowed for official provisions to bring Tibetan immigrants into the country, in an initial wave of around 1000, by way of visas. The Central Tibetan Administration (CTA), in an effort of fairness, hosted a lottery of sorts, to determine who would receive these visas and by the late 1990s, the Tibetan population in the United States had risen to about 5,500, due mostly in part to the success of the initial 1000 and the desire of many others to reunite with family members who migrated in this first wave.

Since then, there has been a steady stream of Tibetan immigrants and refugees, both in and out of the United States, with more contemporary estimates placing the overall population somewhere around 11,000. Major areas of settlement include New York City, Northern California, Colorado, and Virginia (among many others), and the effects of their culture can be seen in others, like Austin, Texas.

Click one of the three American cities on the map to learn more about the Tibetan Communities they each host.


(From Wisdom Quarterly: a Tibetan cultural ceremony in Sacramento)

title: The Tibetan Community in Charlottesville
desc:
Despite being a small, southern city, Charlottesville has an "international neighbor" population of over 6%, and is one of Virginia's leaders in refugee resettlement-- including many refugees from Tibet. Families and individuals are resettled in Charlottesville through Amnesty International's International Rescue Committee (IRC). The Charlottesville office resettles about 250 people per year, and many different Charlottesville organizations and volunteers work to support and welcome these refugees. 


(the Tibetan Association of Charlottesville during a 2008 march downtown)

The first stop for all refugees, regardless of origin, is the INC. link(International Neighbors Charlottesville,https://internationalneighbors.org). The extensive nonprofit covers immediate, physical needs of newly arrived families, but also continues to support them as they engage with an American city. Everything from gym memberships and dental care plans to "bilingual buddies" program for children is covered by the INC. One of their most popular programs is "Family Friendships," where volunteers are matched with a family/individual to help them adjust. 

In the case of Charlottesvillian Tibetans, support often is found in a several devoted and hardworking individuals. Like Tsetan Nepali, a UVA Tibetan language professor who gives traditional music lessons to American-born Tibetan children. Or salon owner Gyaltsen Druknya, who worked tirelessly to help establish link(Arura Medicine of Tibet,http://www.aruramed.org)


(From Cville Weekly: Tsetan in his studio)

UVa itself has an excellent Tibet Center which engages students, staff, and faculty in the scholarship, research, and practice of Tibetan studies. Some of UVa's biggest strides in the digital humanities program occur through the Tibet Center, which also promotes participatory learning.  And the University Hospital works with Arua Medicine of Tibet to introduce traditional Tibetan care into Western medical practices.

One of the more remarkable events in Charlottesville-Tibet relations came in 2008, when City Council voted to fly the Tibetan flag over City Hall in honor of Tibetan National Uprising day-- there was even a march along Main Street and past the Rotunda.


The Tibetan Association of Charlottesville has not been very active of late, but the Jefferson Tibetan society, which teaches and practices the Tibetan Buddhist tradition, continues to spark cultural connections, including spiritual readings, traditional meditation, and discussion of the Mahayana tradition. Charlottesville churches, like UnityChurch, often support visiting monks and "refugee monasteries" who make Charlottesville a stop on educational and spiritual tours. 

And of course, in 2012, the Dalai Lama visited Charlottesville. He gave several talks on religion, ethics, and medical care to packed and enthusiastic crowds at the Paramount Theater and the Sprint Pavilion-- it was a seminal moment for Charlottesville as its relationship with Tibetan refugees continues to strengthen.

(the Dalai lama speaking at the Pavilion in Charlottesville)

title: Tibetans in Colorado
desc:
pic(https://info-buddhism.com/Slider-Dharma/cia_tibet.jpg) The story of how Tibetans first ended up in Colorado is one of the most fascinating pieces of history in the Tibetan Diaspora. Early in the 1950s, the United States CIA began involving itself in the affairs of both Tibet and China, by inserting agents in in Tibet to train its citizens in the skills they needed to rebel against Chinese occupation. Gyalo Thondup, brother to the Dalai Lama, assisted the US government in their efforts in the region. Using him as a contact, the CIA was able to bring several Tibetans to a secret facility located near Leadville, Colorado, in order to train them in combat tactics. After several decades of obstacles to the program, including lack of funding and the United States’ growing diplomatic ties with China, it was eventually decommissioned in 1974.page()

pic(http://coloradotibetans.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/west-coast-5-550x400.jpg) Now, Colorado is home to a vibrant, active Tibetan community, one which is one of the most dense concentrations of Tibetans in the US. Following the CIA-Tibet program of the late 20th century, many more Tibetans gradually made their way to Colorado following the Immigration Act of 1990. Colorado is now home to around 300 Tibetans, as well as Naropa University, a private school founded by a Tibetan Buddhist teacher and focused on traditional Tibetan Buddhist ideals. The Tibetan Association of Colorado was founded in 1999, and serves as not only a liaison between the Tibetan community and those in surrounding areas, but also as an internal educator and preserver of Tibetan culture.

title: Tibetans in New York City
desc:
pic(http://s1.ibtimes.com/sites/www.ibtimes.com/files/styles/lg/public/2014/10/02/occupy-central-rally-new-york_4.JPG) While there is no real consensus on just how many Tibetans are living currently in New York City, general estimates place the total number somewhere between 5 and 6 thousand, making it one of the largest concentrations in the Western world. Like most communities in the United States, NYC did not, in any significant fashion, see an influx of Tibetan immigration until the passing of the Immigration act of 1990. Once this legal and political roadblock had been cleared, however, the city became home to more Tibetans than any other in the United States. The Tibetan community in New York City is incredibly diverse, with refugees from Tibet itself, from India, Nepal, and Bhutan, and even transplants from elsewhere in the Western world, relocating to live with their families. Many of these immigrants initially came under tourist visas, and chose to stay, rather than return home. The city largely has no problem with this, as, historically, New York is a hub for immigrants from all walks of life, and has the necessary infrastructure and job opportunities to support them, particularly in the service industries.page()

pic(http://assets.nydailynews.com/polopoly_fs/1.1918168.1409099110!/img/httpImage/image.jpg_gen/derivatives/article_750/momo27q-2-web.jpg) Unlike other cities, like Toronto, where the Tibetan populations are centered in one particular area, the Tibetans living in New York are somewhat more evenly distributed, although small clusters exist in Queens and Brooklyn. Jackson Heights for example, a neighborhood in Queens, is home to a concentration of Tibetan businesses and their respective owners. However, business ownership is not typical, with many Tibetan women working as housekeepers, babysitters, and various other home-based occupations, and the majority of men working service-industry jobs in restaurants or in janitorial positions. However, due to the undocumented nature of many of these Tibetans, as well as generally poor record keeping and non-distinction from the Chinese by official government sources, a full range of economic information about these transplants cannot be conclusively stated.page()

pic(https://st.depositphotos.com/1955233/4858/i/950/depositphotos_48584499-stock-photo-tibetans-represented-tibet-in-the.jpg) Tibetans in New York are engaged in some of the most extravagant and public cultural events in the Western world. The Tibetan New Years and the birthday of the Dalai Lama in particular are massive events in the New York City Tibetan community, with parades and parties held all over the city. These events serve a dual purpose, as they not only allow Tibetans to celebrate their culture and unify with one another, they also allow the non-Tibetan public to observe and participate in their culture. Likewise, the Tibetan community is largely integrated in many other cultural events in the city, most notable of which is the International Cultures Parade, showing that the larger New York community is just as willing to include Tibetans in their events as well.

title: Tibetans in Austin, Texas
desc:
pic(https://janetstpaul.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/07/tibetan-monks.jpg) The city of Austin, Texas is a prime example of the way in which aspects of Tibetan culture has spread and permeated the Western world, even in areas without a significant amount of actual Tibetan inhabitants. While there is a small population of Tibetans in Austin, their impact on the area is much less a result of their physical presence, and much more to do with the West’s adoption of several cultural aspects of Tibetan life, the most significant of which is Tibetan Buddhism.page()

pic(http://www.palri.org/images/498_ll_tib_sangha_web.jpg) Austin is home to a thriving Buddhist community. The city hosts dozens of temples, meditation centers, religious education facilities, and several other establishments focused on Buddhist rituals and traditions. Buddhist traditions from Sri Lanka, India, and Tibet, as well as from smaller, fringe sects are all represented here. And while not all of these facilities are based in Tibetan Buddhist, there is still a significant Tibetan presence. For example, the Palri Pema Od Ling temple is one of the city’s most popular Buddhist destinations. Adorned with a large, ornate statue of Guru Rinpoche, who historically helped to construct the first Buddhist temple in Tibet sometime in the 8th century, the temple is headed by Lama Lobtsul, an ordained monk born and raised in Tibet. With an actual, “authentic” Tibetan religious leader, the temple is one of the few places in the United States that boasts an opportunity for eager converts to educate themselves on Tibetan Buddhist traditions. See the next page to get a better look at the temple and the day-to-day events held there.page()

page()

pic(https://texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metapth301547/m1/1/med_res/) The city of Austin is also home to the Tibetan Association of Austin, who, as their name suggests, seeks to keep traditional Tibetan rituals and customs alive through performances and educational events designed to not only entertain, but also to teach the public about Tibet.

title: The Dalai Lama
desc:
The Dalai Lama, in the decades following his exile from Tibet, has been one of the main driving forces in unifying the various Tibetan communities scattered around the globe. He has become, among other things, the face of Tibet and Tibetan Buddhism, not only within the culture and religion itself, but within the wider world as well. He is a spiritual, political, and social leader, serving as an anchoring point for the thousands of Tibetans spread all over the world. And most importantly, he serves as a singular, identifiable figure by which all Tibetans, no matter where they happen to be, can recognize, learn from, and ultimately rally behind, making him one of the most powerful and influential people in modern age.

In Popular Culture

Part of the Dalai Lama’s effectiveness in unifying not only the Tibetans in various regions of the world, but all other groups of Buddhists and general practitioners of Eastern religions as well, is his sheer prominence in the media and popular culture. Advances in technology in the past several decades has made it increasingly easy for the Dalai Lama to communicate with his followers en masse, allowing him to both educate them and bring them together in mutually-beneficial platforms of discussion.

He makes frequent appearances on television and other entertainment media, spreading awareness of both Tibet and Tibetan Buddhism. He is relatively active on social media, particularly Twitter (you can see some recent posts below), where he gives inspirational messages, and also occasionally announces speaking events and other educational and community opportunities. His link(website,https://www.dalailama.com/) also allows for his followers to track his schedule, read news about Tibet and its people, and generally stay informed on all aspects of their culture. These tools allow for an incredible amount of transparency and accessibility to the Dalai Lama and his affairs, which gives his followers a wealth of tools in which to both see and hear him and his teachings, as well as communicate with one another, through events organized by him and his various organizations.

The Kalachakra

The Kalachakra is an extremely important system in Tibetan Buddhism. It has a somewhat dual definition, referring to both a deity-like figure, as well as a series of ritualistic traditions. The deity represented by the Kalachakra is a Tantric one, representing a figure that has achieved enlightenment, and as such, perceives time from a perspective of total omniscience. The concept of time is essentially the heart of the Kalachakra, with the name itself meaning “Cycle (or Wheel) of Time.” It represents not only the cycle of time, but all other cyclical concepts as well, from astrological cycles of planets and stars, to physical biological cycles like breathing, to cycles of energy within the spiritual body. These concepts are expressed through a complex Tantra. In visual representations of the Kalachakra through Mandalas, the Kalachakra deity is positioned directly in the center, in his palace, surrounded by various other pieces of Buddhist iconography.

It is a primary goal for practitioners of Tibetan Buddhism to learn about the Kalachakra, and how to shape one’s mind to a perspective that allows one’s self to understand and identify with the deity and the concepts behind it, on the path to enlightenment. In essence, the Kalachakra is all about understanding the natural organization and structure of the universe, from both a physical and a spiritual perspective, and how everything ultimately exists in a state of perpetual cyclical motion.

For a more detailed breakdown of the Mandala representation of the Kalachakra and all of its components, click link(here,http://kalachakranet.org/mandala_kalachakra.html)

The role of the Dalai Lama in the Kalachakra is one of a teacher and an initiator. To begin practicing the rituals of the Kalachakra, one must be first educated on all the intricacies of the rituals, as well as then be given permission to practice them. As such, the Dalai Lama himself performs Kalachakra initiation ceremonies all around the world, in order to allow those who wish to practice the ritual, and therefore take further steps towards enlightenment, to do so. This practice is extremely fitting, as one of the Kalachakra Tantra's most important features is that it is given for a community. By teaching more and more people the Kalachakra, The Dalai Lama is not only allowing more and more people to properly practice Tibetan Buddhist traditions, he is also bringing them together as a unified body, as the Initiation rituals garner massive audiences.

The blue dots on the map are every Kalachakra the Dalai Lama has performed since exiled, starting in 1954. Click on each dot to find the diversity of cities and the attendance for each ceremony. The most recent event, in India, drew 200,000 recorded attendees.

The Kalachakra ceremony itself is extremely complex, spanning over more than a week. In a nutshell, the ceremony serves to educate the attendees on exactly how to practice the Kalachakra Tantra. Students must pledge to honor and preserve the teachings they are given during this period, although the extent to which they do so is ultimately up to the individual. The centerpiece of the Kalachakra initiation is the construction of the Kalachakra Mandala. This is done by the Dalai Lama himself, who sits center-staged, flanked by various scrolls and iconographic symbols. After the Mandala is constructed, the students are then given various ritualistic rites, and are then allowed to view the Mandala. The ceremony ends with a series of prayers led by the Dalai Lama and the careful removal of the Mandala.

To read a detailed explanation of the entire Kalachakra ritual, click link(here,https://www.namgyalmonastery.org/the-kalachakra-tantra/kalachakra-initiation).

Click on the blue dots to see the years, location, and attendance of the Dalai Lama's Kalachakra rituals.

title: Global Tibet
desc:
Gonkar Gyatso's fifth iteration in the My Identity series was painted in 2014. It encapsulates Gyatso's maturing understanding of a global Tibet-- a Tibet with one foot in and one foot out of a western, modern world. Gyatso is very aware of the fractious self-identity that faces Tibetans in the diaspora.

"Emotionally and ethnically I am Tibetan," he explains, "but socially and politically I feel British, since Britain is the country that granted me citizenship and gave me rights and a sense of national belonging."

And yet, Gyatso doesn't see the introduction of modern, capitalist values into Tibetan culture as all negative. In an link(interview, https://www.artspace.com/magazine/interviews_features/meet_the_artist/meet_the_artist_gonkar_gyatso-5660) with Artspace, he describes the necessity of striking a balance:

"The problem with modern practice is that its objectification of culture is often exploitative and leaves those who gave birth to the culture at the losing end. On the other side, when religious practice becomes too extreme it can be oppressive. My ideal is a co-existence between the two and I try to reflect that through my work.

Gyatso's skillful and thought-provoking combinations of Western and Tibetan Buddhist imagery is emblematic of a culture in flux.

“Just as the identity of my homeland cannot be separated from religion and politics, so my own sensibility has been shaped by the undeniable bond between the two."

NGOs

Despite being scattered all over the world, the individual Tibetan communities that have developed in the wake of the Diaspora do not exist in isolation. Rather, due to a steadily increasing number of factors, these small, pocket communities are becoming more and more connected with one another, creating, for lack of a better term, a Global Tibet, outside of Tibet itself. Technology has played a huge role in this, with services like WeChat allowing Tibetans to communicate with one another, worldwide, even in areas with restrictive communications policies (although whether or not services like these are actually secure is up for debate).

One of the most unifying forces of the Global Tibetan community, besides the Dalai Lama himself, is the existence of an extensive network of Non-Governmental Organizations, or NGOs. These NGOs exist on a massive, global scale, with literally dozens, if not hundreds of them existing in almost every nation that hosts Tibetan citizens, and even some without. These organizations usually take the form of community centers, but can also be the headquarters of various political and social movements, namely Free Tibet.

All of these NGOs operate under the organizational structure of the International Tibet Network, which maintains a record of all its individual branches, and helps to organize events and information between them. Through the International Tibet Network, Tibetans, as well as those who support their struggle, have banded together to form a super-group of interconnected organizations, helping to maximize their political, social, and cultural effectiveness worldwide.

Click link(here, https://tibetnetwork.org/) to visit the website of the International Tibet Network.

title: About this project
desc:
www.viseyes.org/identity

This visualization is about the profound changes experienced by Tibetans in Tibet and in the diaspora context over the last decades. It is the final assignment of Introduction to the Digital Liberal Arts (Media Studies 3703), a project-based learning class that uses interactive technology to explore topics in the humanities. In this presentation, students look into how Tibetan identity has gained new and complex features using contemporary artist Gonkar Gyatso’s work as a guide to the geopolitical, religious, and cultural changes in Tibet and beyond Tibet, from traditional times to the modern diaspora. The result is an interactive visualization using SHANTI's VisualEyes tool that tells the story in an engaging manner.

UVA research seminars (RSEMs)

This class is a prototype of an evolving effort at the University of Virginia to connect undergraduate students and faculty in creating an interactive visualization that invites deep inquiry into that faculty member’s research interests. These seminars use the project-based learning instructional approach to encourage an authentic relationship between the students and a faculty member’s research activities. Students develop meaningful research questions through exploring, structuring, and analyzing primary sources and successfully communicate their findings using modern technological approaches.

The process

The class was divided into two parts. In the first, we read many articles and book chapters on Tibet and discussed them in class. We also read chapters and articles on various aspects of interactive visualization. These readings were supplemented with lectures in equal measure on both topics, guest lectures by three religious studies scholars.

Students were asked individually to make a simple visualization using the VisualEyes to understand the mechanics behind the tool. During the latter portion of this half, we began to discuss what a visualization encapsulating our readings and lectures might look like.

The second half started out with class discussion that honed the subject of the project finer and we all decided to use Gonkar Gyatso’s paintings as a framework to talk about change in Tibet. The class was divided into four groups, with each one focusing on one of the paintings and class time alternated between small group meetings and whole class discussions and feedback on their individual portions.

We made great use of Google Docs to facilitate communication both within the groups and a mechanism for the instructors to “stay in the loop” during class time. The latter portion of class time was spent on groups finishing their part of the visualization, culminating in a public presentation at UVA’s historic Rotunda 12/5/17.

Student groups

The Traditional group was made up of Katrina DeFilippo, Margaret McCoy, and Jane Nelson.
The Chinese Tibet group was Anne Morgan Hunter, Abigail Lague, and Brent Reutter.
The Indian Diaspora group consisted of Cory Harris, Hannah Mussi, and James Swanson.
The World Diaspora group was Shane Brooks and Isabella Ciambotti.

About VisualEyes

VisualEyes is an HTML5 web-based authoring tool developed at the University of Virginia to weave images, maps, charts, video and data into highly interactive and compelling dynamic visualizations. VisualEyes enables scholars to present selected primary source materials and research findings while encouraging active inquiry and hands-on learning among general and targeted audiences.

VisualEyes was started at the Virginia Center for Digital History and was funded by grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities with continued support from the University of Virginia's Sciences, Humanities & Arts Network of Technological Initiatives (SHANTI). VisualEyes is freely available for academic and non-profit use. See www.viseyes.org for more information.

Instructors

Bill Ferster is a research professor at the Curry School of Education at the University of Virginia and the Director of Interactive Visualization at UVA’s Sciences, Humanities and Arts Network of Technological Initiatives (SHANTI) where he develops tools for the digital humanities and teaches classes in historical visualization. He is the author of Interactive Visualization: Insight through Inquiry (MIT Press 2012), Teaching Machines: Learning from the intersection of education and technology (Johns Hopkins 2014), and Sage on the screen: Education, Media, and How We Learn. (Johns Hopkins 2016). In previous lives he founded a number of technology companies in the film and television industry. bferster@virginia.edu

Ana Cristina O. Lopes is a lecturer at the Department of Religious Studies at UVA. Specializing in the study of Buddhism, anthropology of expressive forms, visual anthropology and globalization, she has conducted years of fieldwork throughout Asia, Europe, and the Americas and has held appointments as visiting scholar at Harvard and NYU. She is the author of the book Tibetan Buddhism in Diaspora: Cultural Re-signification in Practice and Institutions (Routledge 2015), a pioneering work concerning the contemporary global spread of Tibetan Buddhism. She has recently finalized her first ethnographic movie Kalachakra: Circle of Time, a 73-minute visual essay about the 2012 Kalachakra Initiation presided over by the Dalai Lama in Bodhgaya. ao9w@virginia.edu
